That $23,000 is not a lot of money before Youth Allowance starts to cut out because of the Parental Income Test.

Those quotes are from this strategy document. However, instead of actually fixing what is wrong with the legislation, the government has decided that it is going to spend taxpayers' moneyâwaste moneyâon glossy promotional campaigns which will fool no-one. The strategy acknowledges that there is widespread concern about this particular policy. It acknowledges that the concern comes from the Australian Council of Social Services, the National Union of Students and the Australian Youth Policy and Action Coalition, which it describes as `predictable'. It also describes the voluble opposition from religious groups and churches.
The department obviously views the criticism from the two latter groups as more of a threat, because the document states:
. . . they will have credibility with middle Australia as well as those families affected by the Parental Income Test.

From the lists and comments contained in this departmental document, we can pretty safely assume that one of the chief aims of the strategy is to discredit some of these so-called `predictable' organisationsânot to mention the church, religious and community groupsâon this particular issue. To the same degree that youth groups or other advocacy organisationsâand heaven forbid that any organisations might dissent from government line or policyâhave already been sidelined, the attempt is to discredit them further.

We should not forget that the strategy also takes the remarkable step of sidelining and targeting two individual members of parliamentâmyself from the Democrats and Jenny Macklin from the Labor Party in the other House. Apparently, we are spreading `negative publicity' and for that reason we have been singled out as people who should be counteracted. Some people have suggested that we should be flattered that the government feels that we are such a threat to its policy that it expends time and energy singling us out in documents. While it is clear that this document shows the extent to which groups such as the Democrats are perceived as a real threat by this government, it is unfortunate that the government is not prepared to defend the policy of the common youth allowance proposal on its merits, instead of singling out, criticising and counteracting individuals.

I am amazed that the sustained efforts of my party and others to scrutinise and expose the regressive elementsâand there are retrograde aspectsâof this legislation have been branded as negative publicity by the department when, in fact, we are scrutinising, analysing and highlighting elements which we believe will negatively and adversely affect middle and lower income families in Australia.

I would be more than happy to spread some positive news. I would be more than happy to talk in the community and in the media about positive initiatives from this government in relation to young people and policy affecting them. Unfortunately, the government has not given me a lot to go out and talk about in a positive or up-beat mannerâit is resorting to McDonald's placemats to do that.

If the government cannot handle criticism of its legislationâand, as the House of review, the responsibility of this chamber is to analyse, amend if necessary or appropriate, scrutinise and review legislationâthen it should actually amend its policy, and not try to gloss over the real concerns of a variety of representative bodies. By all means, the groups mentioned within that strategy document are representative and, in most cases, grassroots organisations.

The Democrats have long opposed a number of policy measures contained in the common youth allowance legislation. That is because we believe that they are retrograde and, in many respects, deeply unfair to young people and their families. Let's remember that lower to middle income families will be most negatively affected by these changes. Let's look at a number of those changes. There is the parental means test, which kicks in at an incredibly low threshold of around $23,400 per annum, and also the fact that 16- and 17-year-olds who are not in employment, education or training are going to lose their benefits. They are going to be completely dependent, morally and financially, on their families. The government still has not responded to the concerns of religious and other community groups as to how those young people and their families are expected to survive.

The concocted notion of what constitutes an age of independence is another aspect of the legislation that we have great difficulty with. The premise of the legislation is flawed because it relies on the belief that young people should be financially and otherwise dependent upon their families well into adulthood. This ignores the social and economic realities of Australian life for young people and their families.

We do not believe that young people and their families should be forced to undergo unreasonable and undue hardship as a result of this almost philosophical notion perpetuated by the government that families should be responsible for their children until they have reached these concocted ages of independence. Let's remember how high those ages are: 21 for young adults and 25 for young students. We are not talking about teenagers; these are young adults who are expected to be dependent upon their families and who will be judged according to their parental income.

The common youth allowance sets up this moral obligation for parents to support young adults where there is no legal obligation in any other existing legislative framework. Entitlement will be subject to an incredibly harsh means test. As I said, the parental means test kicks in at just over $23,000âthat is below average weekly earnings. That is a low level. No wonder families are concerned about the impact of this legislation.

This legislation affects a large number of young Australiansâaround 560,000 young people will be eligible for some form of the youth allowance, of which approximately 70 per cent will be students. Government figuresâand we are prepared to use government figures, although I believe they are probably quite a conservative estimateâestimate that 33,250 or around six per cent of young people will be receiving less money as a result of the common youth allowance, and 12,800 young people who currently receive some form of assistance will not receive anything at all under the new scheme. Is it any wonder that they and their families are responding negatively or with concern to the introduction of the CYA?

These are just some of the measures that are contained within the government's policy. These are aspects which the Democrats have exposed, opposed and tried to amend. Community groups, churches, and young people and their families are well aware of the potential negative impact of the common youth allowance. They know the impact that that will have on their lives and, potentially, on the community as a whole. However, the government should not make the mistake of assuming that these people will be fooled or fobbed off by some kind of glossy promotional campaign or soapie scripts with favourable plot lines in episodes of Home and Away and Neighbours, let alone McDonald's placemats.

If the government wants to win the support of the community on this issue, it should listen to the criticisms of this policy, rather than seeking to silence or target those individuals, community and other advocacy groups which would expose the problems in the legislation. It should change the legislation to make it fair. Only then will people like me, my party and other groups in society sing the government's praises on the issueâwhich we would do if it made the sort of positive changes which take into account some of the realities of family life today.

talk.start.para: âThis is my final speech in a series of three dealing with the study of information technologies and developments in Australia and overseas. This particular speech will deal with telecommunications. Four years ago, I had the opportunity to study what was a new idea at that timeâthe information superhighway in the United States. I said at that time that the Labor government needed to be a lot more pro-active in the development of this information superhighway in Australia.

speech.para: In 1994 there were real concerns about monopoly power, and the duopoly was developing at that time. The ALP really did nothing to allay these fears. The Labor government did not have a policy which would enable third parties to have proper access to the cable roll-out. In the Telecommunications Act 1997 this government has introduced an access regime which will fix the problems which the ALP neglected during its long stewardship.

We will ensure that third parties have access at agreed commercial rates and, if there are any disagreements, this will not be fixed by backroom deals, as was the way in which the roll-out was determined under the previous government. Any disagreements under this government go before the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission. We have this system which, from my study, makes Australia a world leader in this regard. We have one act which covers all telecommunications in Australia, and in that regard we are much better placed than the United States and the United Kingdom.

We have two main players and access for new entrants which will allow them to become telecommunications carriers. This was brought about by our change to the legislation opening up the market in July 1997. This government is dedicated to improving telecommunications services. The float of Telstra will improve service and improve prices. The introduction of competition in the telecommunications market will also give Australians greater choice in terms of services and providers. We have ensured that providers are legally required to put on price caps. There will be untimed local calls, universal service obligations and customer service guarantees.

I believe that the changes brought about under this government make Australian legislation the best in the world in regard to the protection of consumers. The particular consumers that I have a great interest inâas I am based in regional and rural Australiaâare the people outside the capital cities. This government has put Telstra and other telephone carriers on notice to improve telephone services and cater for the needs of rural and regional customers.

Amendments to the Telecommunications Act to introduce penalties of up to $10 million if a phone company fails to comply with the directions of the industry regulator, the Australian Communications Authority, have been put in place. Rural areas will, as a result, have access to first rate telecommunications services as this new information age dawns. From my study, Australia's telecommunications regulatory framework is now world competitive.

But Labor made this success, this change, that was brought about in the last few years, very difficult because, when they did start to grapple with this policy area in the early 1990s, they totally mucked it up. They had the chance to introduce one backbone system throughout Australia through what was called the common trench policyâthat is, you provide, say, down one street a trench that is wide enough for a whole range of telecommunication carriers to have access to.

If the ALP had done this in 1992, it would have headed off the ugly overhead cable roll-out that many cities in this country have been subjected to. It would have saved billionsâlet me repeat that, billionsâof dollars in wasted duplicated infrastructure. Most importantly, it would have prevented the defacing of the environment, as we have in areas like northern Sydney where these ugly cables now hang across the poles down the main streets of those suburbs. It is interesting to note that Europe is now grappling with this issue five or six years on. It seems to be determined to introduce a one-trench policy, which will allow other people to enter the market at lower cost. It is a great pity that, under the previous government, Australia lost that opportunity.

Malaysia, our main regional competitor in attracting information industries, is having big problems in rolling out its telecommunications backbone. Throughout Malaysia, only about 18 per cent of homes are on telephone, and in Kuala Lumpur the figure rises to only 50 per cent. This means a huge capacity exists as the standard of living in that country rises. It is very concerned about creating an information rich and information poor divide in its country as this roll-out continues, and it is looking at some form of subsidy for the roll-out in remote areas.

Grappling with the establishment of this communications trench policy, the Malaysian telecommunications minister was very positive about the Australian government's infrastructure fund idea, which will ensure a more rapid roll-out in the more remote areas of the country. In Australia, we are also gaining a leading edge over our competitors by having a competitive Telstra in competition with companies like Optus and Vodafone. Since deregulation in 1997, a number of small players have been developing niche markets.

I had the opportunity to speak with Optus's parent company, Cable and Wireless, and the discussions focused mainly on Optus. It suggested that competition in Australia will be further improved when Optus gets its act together on telephony software. I was told that the problems Optus has been having here in developing competitive telephony should be overcome by June 1988. We all wait with baited breath to see if that is the case because that will really force down the prices of telephone calls in Australia. The parent company was confident that Optus would be turning a profit in 1999. I also discussed with the parent company that earlier point I made about the Optus overhead cable roll-out and the very poor public perception of this.

In 1994, I warned of the potential dangers of creating an information rich and information poor society in Australia if we did not get this information technology roll-out rightâthe main problem being, of course, companies concentrating on major cities first and rural areas a very distant second. However, probably better than any other country in the world, Australia has now ensured under this government that rural Australia is protected and will receive first-rate service.

In London, I studied the effects of privatisation on British Telecom and the whole area of increased competition. The general consensus was that British Telecom needs to lift its game. I was told that it was still operating like an inefficient monopoly player and that it was not flexible enough to meet niche market demand. It was suggested that the future lay with a lot of small players, players that would have about 10,000 customers and would each meet niche demand and put together capacity, product and billing systems.

I spoke to Telstra UK officials about this competition. They told me that there was overcapacity in the UK market, and Telstra UK believes that the second player in the UK, Mercury, was under pressure, perhaps more than British Telecom, from these new players. Its duopoly position has been threatened at the third player level, who, interestingly enough, is actually going after Mercury, which is the equivalent of our Optus, rather than British Telecom, the equivalent of our Telstra.

Some other corporations that have other functions are actually looking at getting into the telecommunications market as competitors as well, and this is very good news for consumers. Groups that you would not think would have any interest in telecommunications, such as water corporations and electricity corporations, are looking to become players. What do they have in common? They have right of way access. They have paths through which pipes and electricity lines pass. With that right of way access already theirs, they can put through very quickly things like optic fibre. Of course, the other great advantage they have is centralised billing systems.

So, by putting optic fibre through, these sorts of companies can get into telecommunications and create greater competition for the big players and drive prices down further. Those utilities in Australiaâelectricity and waterâwould be in a similar position and could get into this market, if they wished. The opportunity for that, of course, has been provided by the deregulated structure that we have already created.

In Malaysia, interestingly enough, there were considerable problems with the way in which competition was developing. From my observations, Australia is probably developing things in a better way. I met with the Minister for Communications in Malaysia, who, interestingly enough, had taken on this portfolio in 1978. So he was very much across these issues and the way in which it had all developed in Malaysia. Like Australia, they started with Telecom Malaysia. They had a very similar monopoly position to what we had. But they went very quickly from one player to six, and they have discovered that they are too small. As a matter of fact, two companies have actually handed their licences back because they were not viable.

The minister said that further rationalisation is necessary. So, having gone to a very decentralised sort of structure, they have found they have gone too far and are coming more towards the way we are doing it. He suggested that, in terms of Malaysia, three companies would probably enable them to be internationally competitive. All of this suggests that Australia is very much on the right track as we move away from the monopoly to the duopoly and then to an open competition regime. My study of telecommunicationsâfirstly in the US and then more recently in London and Malaysiaâhas offered many very useful insights into Australia's place in the world in this telecommunications revolution that will shape our place in the information age as we move into the 21st century.

talk.start.para: âToday I want to speak about the issue which has occupied so much of the news this morningâthat is, the actions on the Australian waterfront which took place late last night, around midnight, we are informed. It is simply an indication that Mr Reith has played his final card in what has been nothing more than a political campaign against the unions, and, frankly, it is a card dealt from the bottom of the deck. But the issue, as far as we are concerned, is far from over, and we will be pursuing it to the hilt.

speech.para: There is no doubt that Mr Reith and Mr Sharp, until he resigned in disgrace, have driven this process from day one, culminating in the actions today. The process started with the appointment of Mr Paul Houlihan by Mr Reith in March 1996, straight after the election. Mr Houlihan's job was apparently to help draft the Workplace Relations Actâand he was about crafting an act custom-made to launch an assault on organised labour. Mr Houlihan picked up a cool $20,000 for what was, as I understand it, a few weeks work.

Mr Sharp then appointed Mr David Trebeck, a principal of ACIL Economics and a close colleague of Mr Houlihan, to conduct some consultancy research on his plan because his job was to build a strategy around a workplace relations model to get the Maritime Union of Australia, and, of course, Mr Houlihan was there guiding the process as part of the consultancy. Mr Trebeck's appointment followed discussions between former Liberal director Andrew Robb, Trebeck, Houlihan and the then minister for transport, Mr John Sharp. That work laid the foundations for the government's strategy.

Mr Trebeck's work went to the questions of how best to target the MUA and how a stevedore might go about hiring an entire work force. Mr Reith's department became involved on 9 September 1996 when it was briefed by ACIL Economics. A senior officer in Mr Reith's department, Mr Darren Gillespie, met with Mr Chris Corrigan on 25 February 1997. They discussed the option of sacking Patrick's work force back then. Mr Corrigan also met with David Trebeck in Patrick's Sydney office, and, again, the option of sacking the work force was discussed.

On 27 February 1997, Mr Reith received his plan. It was written by Workplace Relationsâhis department, that isâbut it was designed by Trebeck, Houlihan and Mr Reith himself. Its design was to smash the union. The negotiated reforms option in the draft strategy, agreed with officers of the department of transport, was removed by Mr Gillespie without reference to the department of transport officers. He also increased the attractiveness of the confrontationalist option. It is clear Mr Gillespie had his instructions from Mr Reith, and he delivered the product. The Reith plan was exposed through a minute to him dated 10 March 1997. That minute said, in part:

. . . stevedores would need to activate well-prepared strategies to dismiss their work force, and replace them with another quickly in a way that limited the prospect of, for example, the Commission ordering reinstatement of the current work force.

That sounds very similar to exactly what happened at midnight last night. In 1997, the major stevedore, OOCL, was seeking to set up business in Melbourne. It made the fatal error of saying it was prepared to employ unionised labour. So the Howard government and the Kennett government had discussions, and OOCL was forced out. What did that company say? It said it was forced to move to Sydney, the rent was set too high in Melbourne. So competition is okay, but only if the government approves.

The Reith plan was then progressively refined. Dr Stephen Webster was employed, along with a number of other consultants. Dr Greg Feeney, from the department of transport, told an estimates committee that he was instructed by Mr Sharp to employ Webster after a meeting of the cabinet subcommittee established to look at maritime issues. The membership of the committee was Mr Sharp, Mr Reith, Mr Fahey and Mr Costello. What did Dr Webster receive for his involvement in the consultancy? He received $95,000. An associate, Dr John Davies, who, we are told, was engaged by Dr Webster, picked up $96,000âthis for all of 12 weeks work.

Dr Webster received a bonus. He was also appointed to a position in Minister Reith's ministerial office. In August last year, on the recommendation of Dr Webster, Mr Sharp engaged Minter Ellison at a cost of $151,000 to get the legal basis for an attack on the union set up. In August last year, Australasian Research Strategies, the company of Liberal pollster Mark Texter, was commissioned to provide a report on community attitudes to the MUA and the docks, and that report cost $42,000. I might say, it is not the Liberal Party which is paying these consultancies; it is the Australian public.

Mr Texter found that the waterfront was not a top-of-the-mind issue, but there was concern about international competitiveness. So another Liberal strategist, Jonathan Gaul, was engaged to develop a political communications strategy around the Texter research. What was the theme? The theme, which we have heard many times from Mr Reith, was that wharfies are privileged. They do not receive $96,000 for 12 weeks work, but they are privileged.

While the Reith plan was being refined, so was that of the NFF. According to Mr Houlihan, `The window of opportunity came in August when we heard Patrick was losing money at Webb Dock.' In the meantime, Mr Reith tried to break the union in Cairns, but he failed. Mr Greg Bondar, the senior maritime adviser to Sharp at the time, was later quoted as sayingâ

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator should be required to at least show the courtesy of addressing people in the other place by their correct titles.
âI said `Mr Reith'.

âYou should refer to Mr Sharp and Mr Reith, and you should also perhaps refer to Mr Wran and Mr Turnbull in relation to their payments for their consultancies to the previous government on the sale of ANL.
âPeople should be referred to by their correct titles.
âOn that matter, Mr Acting Deputy President, I believe that referring to Mr Reith as `Mr Reith' is sufficient. Are you saying that I need to give him his full title?
âNo.

âThank you. Of the Cairns operation, Mr Bondar said, `It was initiated by Peter Reith's department, but I think, in a way, it got out of hand.' So Mr Reith, along with Mr Sharp, then attacked the employersâit was their fault, apparently. Mr Reith said that the government had created the framework, but no-one would use it. Mr Sharp said, `Employers often criticise us, but they are the ones who are responsible for not taking up the new opportunities.' That is, the existing employers would not play the gameâthe game that the government wanted them to play. Mr Richard Hein from P&O said, `We are not about deregistering the MUA.' Apparently he had been asked about that. He also said that P&O was `not about tearing up our agreement and setting out to destroy the MUA'. Apparently he had also been asked about that.

speech.para: This is when the National Farmers Federation came into play. Mr Reith's plan needed a compliant employer, but he could not find one. Mr Reith then moved to get a new employer, and the National Farmers Federation was willing to play. On 18 September last year, Mr Reith, Mr Sharp, Dr Webster and the secretaries to the departments of workplace relations and transport met in Melbourne. The key item on the agenda was the establishment of a new stevedore. Dr Webster told the group that the National Farmers Federation should be brought into the plan. Strangely enough, Ms Wendy Craik and Mr James Ferguson from that organisation were at the venue of the meeting within the hourâwithin the hour, as if they knew about the meeting in advance.

talk.start.para: âWell done; well organised.

âMeanwhile, Patricks continued to deteriorate and it played the Dubai card. I will take up that interjection because it is true, it was well organised and orchestrated. This was all part of the plan, Senator Crane; thank you for your confirmation. It went badly wrong. Corrigan originally denied Patricks involvement. But later he had to confess that he had been untruthful. Mr Reith might not have known about Dubai. He knew the workers were being trained; he just did not know where.

speech.para: Mr Houlihan started talks with Mr Corrigan in November of last year. The plan was set up over Christmas and Mr Reith was briefed on 6 January. On 29 January, at 2.30 a.m.âfunny how these things happen the middle of the nightâthree buses carrying 45 security guards entered No. 5 Webb Dock. This was the arrangement between Patrick and the National Farmers Federation. Patrick and the National Farmers Federation are the common theme. The common theme is also doing things in the dark of night. This is the industrial relations style of Mr Peter Reith, and this is his waterfront reform style. We see its culmination today in the mass sackings of 1,400 workers.

talk.start.para: âBetter than Bob Hawke in Peter Abeles' pocket over the airlines.

âSenator Heffernan, I am interested to hear your intervention, because the fact of the matter is that the National Farmers Federation purports to represent farmers, and I know that you are oneâat least part time. But I put a motion to the Senate yesterday on the pork industry. I saw Ms Wendy Craik in the building yesterday. But did I hear anything from Ms Craik about the pork industry? Not a word. The pork industry has 12,000 employees and additional people around the country. It appears to me that the National Farmers Federation was not interested in the issue of protecting the jobs of more than 12,000 people in rural Australia employed in the pork industry. Maybe that is the reason, Senator Heffernan, that a lot of people around the country are saying NFF stands for `not for farmers'.

speech.para: Frankly, the sackings that have taken place as a part of the government's plan, the government's conspiring with these employers and other organisations, are outside of its own law.

talk.start.para: âTell us about Bob Hawke and Peter Abeles conspiring, you hypocrite.

âThank you. I will get you to withdraw that later. The sackings are outside the terms of the government's own law. The hypocrisy of this government in setting a law to protect the rights of people to belong to an organisation and then setting about getting them sacked for that very reason is hypocrisy at its ultimate. Sacking the people was also outside the terms of the stevedoring industry agreement that Patrick had as to how it should go about terminating an employee. So they were not interested in agreements they had signed. They were not interested in principle. They were interested implementing the plan.

speech.para: We had a conspiracy to breach the Workplace Relations Act, we had a conspiracy to breach the agreement and there was a failure to abide by the terms of that agreement. Did Mr Reith know about the plan? Of course he did, because he said a couple of things in his press conference today. He said, `What we have been doing in putting in place our policy strategy'â

talk.start.para: âYou are a hypocrite.
âOrder! Senator Campbell, I ask you to withdraw that; it was unparliamentary.
âMr Acting Deputy President, do you intend asking this person from the opposition to withdraw his use of the word `hypocrisy' on a number of occasions? Indeed, Mr Acting Deputy Presidentâ
âIt is not the word `hypocrisy'.

âI think of the word hypocrisy to describe a Labor Party senator who gets up and talks about sacking workers and conspiracies in the dead of the night when they stood by and did not say a word when Sir Peter Abeles and Bob Hawke sacked all the Australian airline stewards. That is nothing short of absolute hypocrisy.
âOrder! Senator Campbell, you have been asked to withdraw.
âI withdraw.
âThank you.

âMr Reith said today, `What we have been doing is putting in place our policies,' and he meant his strategy. He said also, `Discussions have intensified in the last few weeks on the redundancy issues.' So he was in the cart, he knew what was happening. He might not have known the exact timetable but he knew what was happening. He knew that these people were to be dis missed and he was part of the plan. It was his plan, in fact.

speech.para: But what else has been happening? Mr Reith has been talking about rorts on the waterfront. Let me tell the Senate what happened in my state today. In Tasmania there are only about 30 Patricks employees out of the 1,400 that have been sacked. They have all been sacked. In Burnie there was a ship in port. The people were sacked at midnight, when the ship was loaded with cargoâno thought about that; they were just sacked. No plans in place. What was on the ship? A valuable cargo of horses. Who was interested? The RSPCAânot Patricks, not the government. So what happened? These people who had been sacked, these people who were supposed to be involved in nicking off whenever they could, what did they do? They had been sacked, they were not getting any money, but they went in and unloaded the horses.

Last week, at that very terminal, the employees of Patricks achieved a cargo handling rate, on average over the week, of 33 containers per hour. Did they get thanked for that? This is the performance of people who were so inefficient they had to be sacked. This is the performance of this employer, so unprincipled that it is prepared to reward the good work of its workers by sacking them. That is what Patricks is prepared to do.

What happened in Brisbane today? The complicity of the Queensland Government, through the Port of Queensland Corporation, resulted in guards on the road leading into the Fisherman Islands wharf, in Brisbane. What did they do? They refused admission to 70 P&O workers when they arrived to start work. They were not employed by Patricks. They were going to stop them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to invite another of the kings of slur, Mr Duncan Kerr, in the other place, to take the 15 steps of courage out of that place and repeat some of the things that he has said with regard to my family and me, or to apologise. He has a simple choice. In the time I have, I want to deal with some of these things. Despite the personal explanation I made, despite the answer that was given by Senator Robert Hill, Mr Kerr continues to slur my family and meâand he does it in coward's castle, under privilege of parliament. I repeat: I invite him to step outside or to apologise.

speech.para: The first point I would make goes back to 3 March. After a full explanation in the Senate by our leader, Senator Hill, and a personal explanation by me, Mr Kerr still went into the other chamber and said:
My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the Minister for the Environment has acknowledged in the Senate that an NHT grantâ
a Natural Heritage grantâ
benefited Senator Crane?
That was said despite what Senator Hill had said, and also what I myself had said:

When the applications went outâthey were sent out by the local committeeâmy son, who now runs the property, did not respond. We did not put in any application whatsoever for funding. If you had listened carefully to Senator Hill's explanation, you would have got that. If you can read and you read the letter on the table, you will get it twice. Also, our property will receive no funding whatsoever from the Natural Heritage Trust.

After I had said that, what happened the next day? Senator Bishop, who I do not believe wrote the questionâI believe he was forced into saying itâreferred to the `Crane project' and asked, referring to me, `How much funding did you approve?' Senator Hill replied:
The honourable senator goes very close to misleading in that question but not quite as close as Mr Kerr yesterday.
Even though there were two answers referring to the matter and putting the public record straight, these people continued with it.

What happened, then, on 31 March, just last week? You on the other side may talk about the dark of the night. If ever there was an occurrence in the dark of the night, and a slur and a trying to hide behind something, this is it. Typical of what happened with Senator Robert Ray, Mr Kerr then tried to denigrate us. Realising that we had received no money, we had made no application, what did he do? He said:
Senator Crane comes in and says that he is an expert on landcare groups.
Let me tell Mr Duncan Kerr, `Wrong. I did nothing of the sort.' But I will say that I have had a lot of experience in Landcare and I am very proud of my record in promoting it. Then he said:
But Senator Crane apparently did not even know that his family was involved in a landcare group right in his own backyard.
I say to Mr Duncan Kerr, `Wrong again. We were among the people that started the Landcare group there.' He continued his slur program. He said:
Some expert! He did not even know that his particular property intersected with a group that was funded.
Of course I did not damn well know. I knew nothing about it. What is more, there had been no funds granted at the time when this matter came up. Mr Kerr continued:
So there he was in there with the minister, rorting Western Australian grants to go to coalition held seats . . .
Once again, that is absolutely, totally wrong. And the slur king is at again, as are many of his colleagues on the other side of the chamber.

In the short time I have available, I would like to quote a couple of things from a letter from the Ravensthorpe Land Conservation District Committee, of which the chairman is Mr Andrew Duncan and the honorary secretary is Mrs Madeleine Norman. Rick Farrell, the catchment support officer, the signatory to the letter, says in relation to the study:

In the course of the study, John Platt spent time in the catchment surveying, visiting individual locations and meeting with landholders. I accompanied John in the field on some occasions and attended all meetings between the group and himself. At no time did either John Platt or myself visit your property. John Platt informed me in the course of a telephone conversation this afternoon, that he had no recollection of meeting with either your son or daughter-in-law (Paul or Nikki) while engaged in the study.

I say once again to these people, `It is about time to take the 15 steps of courage out, or to apologise. You have a lot of people in this place to apologise to, including the late Senator John Panizza, whom you very seri ously slurred.' I am pleased to see Senator Peter Cook over there, because he was the instigator of that slur. I ask, about the process and what those people do in terms of their actions, `Where are your policies? Where are you going to put up?'
We have just heard from Senator O'Brien, with not one constructive comment about what the Labor Party intends to do with regard to the waterfront but just carrying on with the continual slur.

talk.start.para: âIn the muck bucket again.
âIn the muck bucket, absolutely, as Senator Ferris has said. You can go on and read this letter and what is in there. (Time expired)

âMadam President, my question is addressed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Minister, are you aware that the Workplace Relations Act requires that no employee be sacked because they are union members, and that any employer proposing to sack more than 15 employees must advise the CES before doing so? Are you also aware that the stevedoring industry award requires any employer to notify their employees and their union of any definite decision that is likely to have a significant effect on employees, including termination of employment, and obliges the employer to discuss such changes before they come into effect? Can you advise the Senate what steps the government took to satisfy itself that these provisions had been complied with before you supported Patricks' decision to dismiss 1,400 workers to replace them with another work force?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: âFinally the Labor Party has come out of its shell. This dispute has been taking place for monthsâand how many questions have we heard from the Labor Party on it? Not one. There has been no interest until today. Today, however, they come out of the shell and in solidarity say, `We are alongside the workers who have lost their jobs.' It is a bit late, Senator, to be alongside the workers who have lost their jobs.

answer.para: What the Labor Party should have been doing for years was encouraging greater productivity on the wharves. It should have been looking for an efficient waterfront, an internationally competitive waterfront, a waterfront where not only the jobs of stevedores would be assured but also where Australia would benefit through lower export costs and all other Australians would therefore benefit indirectly as well.

So, Senator, it is too late. You have let your fellow workers down because you allowed these rorts on the waterfront to continue for 13 years whilst you were in office. You spent $420 million, I concede, but achieved no increased productivity as well. And that is the problem, Madam President. That is why these workers lost their jobs, because they have not been able to deliver an internationally competitive product. If Australia does not deliver internationally competitive products we all fail, Madam President.

On the detail of the question that was asked, as I understand it, what occurred was that the contract with the labour employing company was terminated, so technically, Senator, I regret that you are in error in the way that you put your question.
Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Carr, stop shouting.

âBut, apart from that matter, the fundamental issue is that no-one will be assured of keeping his or her job unless they are competitive, unless they perform at an internationally competitive level. That is what globalisation is all about. The Labor Party might not like that but, if Australia is to growâ
âYou are a disgrace.
âSenator Carr, stop shouting.

âif we are to provide long-term, secure jobs and benefits for all of the community, then you have to face up to that reality. Thirteen years of Labor failed to deliver on the waterfront. They turned a blind eye to the rorts.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âPeople like Senator Carr turned a blind eye to the rortsâ
âOrder! Senator Carr, I have already twice asked you to stop shouting during this answer. I warn you not to continue to do so.

âThirteen years of Labor government, turning a blind eye to the rorts on the waterfront. Why? Because of the solidarity of the union movement. Why? Because of the financial dependence of the Australian Labor Party on the union movement. That is why you permitted these rorts to take place for 13 years whilst in government.

answer.para: Now there is a government in place that recognises that that is not the future for a competitive Australia. Everyone has to shape up, including the wharfies, but they were not prepared to do so. You know that: that is why you did not ask any questions during the dispute. You knew that: that is why you showed no interest in the dispute until today.

Madam President, we, of course, regret that anyone loses a job. But what this government is about is creating new jobs. There have been 220,000 new jobs since we came to office. We are proud of that, Madam President. But we have achieved it because we recognise that Australia has to be competitive and no longer can Australia afford the sorts of rorts that you allowed on the waterfront during 13 years of Labor government.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, we will wait to see about this alleged arrangement between a labour hire company and Patricks, but, given that the Prime Minister gave a commitment to parliament that the government would only support legal actions on the waterfront, how can the government justify its continuing and generous support for the illegal action because, you see, the dismissal is because they are union members?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: âMadam Presidentâ

âThis is what Labor condoned for so long.

âLabor condoned it. It spent $420 million on the waterfront for no improved productivity at all. What was its alternative to the problems as an alternative government? answer.para: The reforms that we want to see upon the waterfront will end overmanning and restrictive work practices. They will lead to a benchmark of 25 crane movements per hour. They will reduce costs to exporters and importers.
Senator Carr interjectingâ

We stand very grateful to Cheryl Kernot, the new comrade, for helping us put in place reforms that allow the waterfront dispute to be quarantined. Of course, the Labor Party answer is, `You don't quarantine a dispute.' You don't quarantine a dispute, do you, Senator Carr? You try to take out all the waterfront workers. âMinister, you are aware that the Democrats have always supported reform of the waterfront, that we voted for the Workplace Relations Act, and that we want to see that law implemented in an even-handed way.
