And is it not true that if Patricks defaults on the proposed loan, the liability of $250 million will be the taxpayers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to have the acknowledgment from Senator Murray that the changes that we jointly implemented to this act were designed to achieve reform on the waterfront, and they are doing just that. It is a great shame that former Senator Kernot has not come out and acknowledged that in recent times. I have not seen a press release from her today, but presumably it is being drafted at the moment.

answer.para: Senator Murray talked about secondary boycotts. I think those provisions are being effective. This mob would have ripped them out, of course, but the fact that they are there has had a very salutary effect on a number of people who might otherwise have been inclinedâlike Senator Forshaw's former unionâto get out there, rip the place apart, cause the waterfront to come to a stop or, indeed, other industries to come to a stop. There is still talk about it happening with Caltex, but I trust it will not happen. The more important point is that the act is designed to ensure that the waterfront does operate effectively, and I am sure it will do just that.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, do you agree with Mr Walmsley from the Australian Taxation Office when he said last Friday, in regard to dividend streamingâand I quote:

question.para: Trusts, in particular, are employed because there were existing anti-dividend streaming provisions in the law, and trusts provided a fairly simple means of circumventing them.

Minister, will trusts continue to be a fairly simple means of circumventing your new provisions regarding dividend streaming or will high-wealth individuals still be able to make use of trusts in order to stream fully franked dividends?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âWe have had a number of these questions from Senator Cook. What inevitably happens, of course, after the substantive question, is that they get back into the sleaze as quickly as they can. We will wait with interest for the supplementary question to see whether Senator Cook has adopted the practice of himself and his colleagues of recent date and attempt, through some tenuous connection with the first part of the question, to defame and demean a senator on this side.

answer.para: We have brought in, as you are aware, Senator Cook, some measures in relation to trusts which I think have been widely welcomed in the community because they deal with a massive problem with which the Labor Party left the tax system, so this government has taken action in this area. In relation to franking streaming, Senator Cook, you will be aware that we have made a number of announcements to deal with the massive problem of franking streaming.

talk.start.para: âWill they work?

âWe believe our legislation will work, yes. Thank you, Jacinta Collins, for that interjection. We believe the legislation that we have brought in will work and will deal with the problem of franking streaming which was apparent in relation to the current system. So now I will wait, Senator Cook, for the supplementary question to see whether you are as grubby as usual.

âI am surprised that you think they will work. I refer you to the evidence of the tax officer to the Senate inquiry. His evidence did not suggest that they would work perfectly. Minister, will it still be possible for the $2 million minister for coal and his wealthy mates to continue to stream fully franked dividends through the AQRM trust which owns one H class share in QCMM Pty Ltd? Why is it fair for a millionaire minister for resources, whose portfolio includes coal, to avoid paying tax through such tax minimisation schemes when your government wants to impose on struggling Australian families a GST which they will not be able to avoid paying? Why is that fair?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âAnd wasn't I absolutely right? This is one of the king grubs of the front bench of the Labor Party. And there are four of them: Senator Ray, Senator Cook, Senator Faulkner and Senator Conroy.
âSenator Kemp, that is not an appropriate way to refer to senators.

âWasn't I absolutely correct in saying that the supplementary question would lead to a grubby attempt to defame a member of the front bench of this party? We remember your form, Senator Cook. You have set a dreadfully low standard. You have not made one substantive contribution.

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. My point of order does not relate to defending myself, because while Senator Kemp is attacking me he is leaving someone else alone. My point of order relates to relevance. Why won't Senator Kemp answer the question on fairness that has been put to him: why is it fair to allow tax avoid ance by the wealthy while seeking to impose a GST on all other Australians?
âThere is no point of order.

âWhat I was saying was absolutely relevant. He stood up as I predicted and attempted to defame a member of the front bench of this party. What I said to Senator Cook was absolutely relevant. I add that it is relevant to point out that for Senator Cook of all people to stand up and talk about fairness in the tax system when he is well known as the senator who supported R&D syndicatesâ(Time expired)
âThat's a lie!
âSenator Cook, withdraw that.

âMadam President, I withdraw the word but I ask you: when someone does not tell the truth, and repeatedly does not tell the truth, why am I prevented from using the only word Australians understand as to what they have meant?
âSenator Cook, there is an appropriate time to debate answers and it is after question time.

âMy question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Has the minister read a report in today's print media that many working mothers clear only $2 an hour due to high child-care costs? Is it a fact, as outlined in the report, that long day care costs have risen faster than the rate of inflation? Did the report also show that a Brisbane couple earned just a clear $2 a fortnight more when the woman worked 40 hours a fortnight? Does the minister regard this situation as satisfactory?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Colston for the question. Yes, I did see that report. As I have said previously in relation to this matter, there are outliers in every community affected by the child-care changes.
âWhat's an outlier?

âI have been asked what an outlier is. In any consideration there are people at both ends of the spectrum who are affected unduly by any measure that is introduced. The fact of the matter is, Senator Colston, that there has been no change in the work force participation rate of mothers.
âRubbishâ200,000 women have left!

âThose in the Labor Party keep saying `rubbish' but they never consider the facts. The fact is that there has been no change in work force participation by mothers due to child care. I am happy to give those figures.

answer.para: The other side of the coin is that under Labor child-care centres were established not where they were needed. People responded to the incentives given by the Labor Party for the establishment of child-care centres. When we came into government we not only inherited a $10Â½ billion deficit that we had to attack but also inherited problems in the child-care system. There were many child-care centres established where there was no need. Of course, some were unduly affected.

Senator Colston, all of us regret that people on low incomes are unduly affected by changes that are brought in. There are certainly people who have been affected in that regard. But overall it has no effect on the number of people who are putting children into child care. The total labour force participation rate of females with dependent children has remained relatively stable at around 59 per cent since January 1996. There has been no change. The Labor Party does not accept that even though we have presented them with the facts all along.

The government is committed to provide fair and reasonable access to quality child care. Reforms to be introduced on 27 April will improve assistance for around 70,000 families using outside school hours care, ensure that children using child care are appropriately immunised, allow 20 hours a week for families wishing to use child care for non-work related purposes and ensure that new centres are located in areas of high need. We are attacking that problem.

Significant subsidies are available for families using child care. For low income families the government provides around $5,600 a year where there is one child in full-time care and over $12,000 if there are two children in full-time care. That is available to those people who have been mentioned. As I said, those changes will be introduced on 27 April. It is because of that that we see that report today.

The government has also increased assistance for families through the introduction of the family tax initiative which provides up to $900 per annum for a single income family with two children and $400 per annum for a two-income family. The answer to your question, Senator Colston, is that there is a temporary hiatus which will be fixed on 27 April and those people will be covered by that.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, is the Prime Minister not correct in complaining, as he has in his foreword to Mr Costello's little red book:

question.para: Many people are not paying their fair share of tax. Until we improve our system, they will continue to find ways of not paying tax which means that someone else ends up paying their share for them. It is just not fair.

Minister, can you confirm that billions of dollars is lost to revenue through tax avoidance by high wealth individuals, in particular through the abuse of trusts. Is it not true that if the artful dodgers paid their fair share of tax your government would not be pursuing policies like the elderly having to sell their homes to get into nursing homes, pensioners having to resort to using superglue to fix their teeth and the states could get the money to run an effective public health system?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âI rather hoped when Senator Faulkner got to his feet that we were at last going to hear an apology to the Baillieu family for the disgusting slur that he made and which everybody recognises is wrong. What a joke it is to have Senator Faulkner getting up and talking about problems of high wealth individuals when sitting right behind him is Senator Cook, who, as I said, was a great defender of one of the great rorts in the tax systemâR&D syndicates. What a joke it is for him to get up and talk about it when he and his colleagues, led by Senator Sherry, decided that they would attempt to defeat the superannuation surcharge for high wealth individuals.
âThat's a lie! Why don't you tell the truth for once in your life?
âOrder! There is too much noise in chamber.
âAs I was saying, when we brought in the measureâ

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. Can I drew your attention to the fact that Senator Cook once again used the word `lie'. I ask that it be withdrawn. Can I also ask how many times he has to repeat that in the same question time without being thrown out?
âSenator Cook, if you used that word I ask you to withdraw.
âI used that word and I withdraw. Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Kemp has continued to make that charge which he knows to be wrong and which has been proven to be wrong.
âThat is a debating point for you to take up in the debate to take note of answers. It is not appropriate to debate it during question time.
âMadam President, I accept what you say. It has been pointed out to Senator Kemp that this is wrong. He continues to do so.
âSenator Cook, you are continuing to debate the issue.
âSenator Cook, as usual, is a bit slow off the mark because I had moved on to another issue of tax equity and referred to the superannuation surcharge.
âTax!

âWow! Aren't they clever? They are a clever lot. I don't care what anybody says: they are a clever lot. Their leader gets up and talks about the problems of high wealth individuals. When this government brought in the superannuation surcharge, who voted against it? The Labor Party voted against it.

answer.para: Let me now turn to the specific issue of high wealth individuals. Let us recall that Labor were in office for 13 years. During the election campaign, the caretaker period after their 13 years in office, what did Mr Keating and the Treasurer announce? That there were problems, they perceived, with high wealth people avoiding tax. After 13 years the Labor Party discovered a problem in this area. You people are an absolute pathetic joke.

We announced when we came into government that this government was committed to ensuring a fair and equitable tax system. That is one of the driving forces behind the tax reform program that this government has proposed which is, because it is about fairness and because it is about equity, opposed by the Labor Party.

Let me assure the Senate that the government is committed to addressing tax minimisation practices used by some high wealth people. There is no doubt about that. The government has provided the Australian Taxation Office with additional funding, some $19 million over two years. You provided nothing, Senator Faulkner. We have provided $19 million over two years to deal with this problem to enable the establishment of a special task force.

Investigations to date have revealed that some high wealth individuals use trusts to minimise tax. The evidence has been taken into account in the review of trusts. Improvements, I can assure Senator Faulkner, in compliance are expected to generate revenue in the order of $100 million in 1997-98.

I thank Senator Faulkner for the question. It allowed me to remind the Senate of the pathetic effort of the Labor Party in this area and provided me with the opportunity to show that this government is taking action. So, Lurch, thanks for the question.

talk.start.para: âSenator Kemp, would you withdraw that?
âOh, who cares, Madam President?
âIt is not an appropriate way to address a senator.
âOh, I don't mind. Who cares?
âI thank Senator Kemp for the question because it does give me an opportunity to ask this supplementary question to him. It relates to the Prime Minister's comments.
âLook more casual, John.

âYeah, I will. Don't you think, Senator Kemp, that the Prime Minister has a real nerve crying crocodile tears over those who are forced to pick up the tab for tax avoiders when he has a row of them on his front bench, including the most artful tax dodger of them all, Senator Parer?
âOn a point of order: you cannot reflect on a senator in that way. He should withdraw.
âI did not hear the remarks. If unparliamentary remarks were made, he should withdraw.
âLet me repeat them so you can make a ruling, because I believe it is in order. I described Senator Parer as the most artful tax dodger of them all. That is what he is.
âI ask you to withdraw that. It is clearly in breach of the standing orders.
âI withdraw it if it is out of order.
âIt is. It is in breach of the standing orders.
âBut it has been in order before. You know what you are! Resign!
âSenator Faulkner! Order! I remind senators againâ

âI have had a second message from the ABC to advise that there has never been a reaction to question time like there has been today in terms of the number of calls protesting about the behaviour of senators and the noise in the chamber, calls from all over Australia to the ABC at Parliament House and at ABC offices. My own office has had calls constantly throughout question time. I think it is a matter that senators ought to reflect upon.

âMadam President, on a point of order: is it out of order when you are telling the Senate about the reaction from the public and particularly in relation to the ABC for Senator Faulkner to say, `Big deal'?
âI did not hear that.
âI certainly did.
âThere have been so many breaches of the standing orders today all around.
âYou are a low life.
âHe is not denying it.
âSenator Faulkner! Senator Kemp, did you wish to respond to the supplementary question?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âFrankly, I will see what I can do. I do not think there was a supplementary question there; there was a disgraceful, unpleasant attack on a member of the front bench.
âThank you.
âI have not finished, Madam President. If I may continueâ
âIf there was no question, Senatorâ
âIf Senator Faulkner feels so strongly about these matters, it is open for him to go outside the chamber and show a bit of courage for a change.
âSenator Kemp, resume your seat please!
âMadam President, on a point of order: I just thought that you were calling Senator Kemp to order and he was ignoring your order.
âThank you. I call Senator Stott Despoja.
âOh, the celebrity senator.

âYou wish, Senator Alston. My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, in the recent tendering out of employment services, why was it a precondition of attending a debrief that unsuccessful organisations agreed to be audio taped? Why were these organisations not informed of the purposes of this audio taping? Can you inform us now as to these purposes? Minister, perhaps you could outline why some of the organisations were unsuccessfulâthat is, some of the reasons that these unsuccessful tenderers were given at that particular briefing session?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: âAll tenderers, and there were a 1,000-odd tenderers, were approached by the department with an opportunity for a debriefing session. Some 670 of those, I understand, requested such a debriefing session and 400 of those have been conducted. At those debriefing sessions, there was present a representative from the department and a solicitor, I understand, from Blake Dawson Waldron, which was the firm of lawyers that was advising the department during the course of the tender process. The unsuccessfulâor successfulâtenderers were free to ask questions as to why they were or were not successful. As to the recording, I understand there was a record made of those meetings, but as to whether or not they were told, I was of the impression that they had been told, Senator Stott Despoja. Perhaps you could enlighten me.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question to the ministerâand perhaps he can take it on noticeâis: why was it a precondition? Not only were these groups not informed in advance; it was made a condition that, if they wanted to hear the reasons why they were unsuccessful in their bids, they had to agree to be audio taped. If they were informedâcontrary to what I have heardâperhaps you can tell us why they were not informed as to why they were being taped and for what purposes the tapes would be used.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: âThere are two aspects to this: the question of whether they were informed, and the question as to why the recording was taking place. I will take the latter first. The latter relates to legal advice, and that relates to people who were unsuccessful who might want to take legal action against the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth would have to be very careful in the advice it gave those unsuccessful tenderers, because after a meeting some people would go away with a misunderstanding as to what actually transpired during the course of that conversation. So, to that extent, it was a prudent course of action. As to the advice given to the participants, my understanding was that they were told that there was a recording made, but as to the reason for it, I will take that on notice.
âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âOn Monday, 6 April, Senator Conroy asked me a question. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
On Monday 6 April 1998, Senator Conroy asked me the following question (Senate Proof Hansard 6 April 1998, page 1498):

Can you confirm that your new anti-dividend streaming provisions [in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1997] will not apply to differential dividend amounts paid to different classes of shareholders providing they all receive franked dividends. If so, will it still be possible for a trust holding one class of shares to receive a disproportionate amount of dividends relative to other classes of shareholders providing both classes of shareholders receive franked dividends?

If all shareholders in a company are equally capable of using franking benefits the proposed dividend streaming provisions will not apply. If some shareholders are more able to use franking benefit than other shareholders, the streaming provisions may apply, depending on the particular facts, notwithstanding that all shareholders are paid franked dividends. For example, if one shareholder more able to use franking credits receives a large franked dividend, and another, less able to use franking credit, receives a small franked dividend and, to compensate, other benefits, the proposed dividend streaming rule could apply.

If the franked dividend is paid under a scheme for the disposition of shares for a purpose of conferring a tax advantage in relation to franking, the proposed general anti-avoidance rule in the bill could also apply.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âOn Tuesday, 7 April, Senator Conroy asked me a question. I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
On Tuesday 7 April Senator Conroy asked me the following question (Senate Proof Hansard 7 April 1998 page 1509):

Can the Minister explain how it would be possible for a company to declare notional dividends on shares that do not exist and then classify these dividends as loans to shareholders? Will the government seek to outlaw such practices, given that they are nothing more than an attempt to disguise dividends as loans, hence avoiding tax?

This is very similar to a question that Senator Cook asked of ATO officials on Friday, 3 April 1998, during the Senate Economics Legislation Committee Inquiry into Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.7) 1997.
It is not possible to provide a considered response without knowing the precise details of the transaction being referred to.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âby leaveâMadam President, we are in the third week of sitting and you mentioned the behaviour of senators on both sides of the chamber. I think this is a reflection of the late hours of sitting which has been brought up on previous occasions. I would like you to take note that we have had many late hours. I have spoken about this on previous occasions, and I think we should take note that that behaviour reflects the hours of sitting.
âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to questions without notice asked by Senators O'Brien and MacGibbon today, relating to an industrial dispute on the waterfront.

Madam President, you reported that you had received a significant number of calls, and there had been a number of calls to Parliament House about question time. I have no doubt that that is because of the outrage felt in the Australian community because of what this government has orchestrated in relation to the waterfront. What happened was that at midnight last night, this country was treated to the sight of Australian workers being peremptorily sacked by their employer, Patrick Stevedores, on the spurious groundâand only groundâthat they were members of the Maritime Union of Australia. That is why they were sacked.

These workers have been locked out of their workplaces by security guards who were accompanied by dogs on leashes. That is what industrial relations, Howard and Reith style, is in Australia in 1998. These sackings have been incited by the Howard government; they have been encouraged by the Howard government; and they have been financially supported by the Howard government. The blackest irony is that these actions by the employer are illegal under the government's own Workplace Relations Act. Workers cannot be sacked on the basis of their membership of a union.
Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIf you don't believe that, go and take a very close look at section 170 of your own government's act.

speech.para: The government has actively agitated now for industrial disputation on the waterfront. It has funded private consultants with taxpayers' money to develop the strategy we see in place. The government has been very closely involved at every stageâat Cairns, Dubai, the Webb Dock and now nationwide. The government has consistently refused to constructively work for proper reform on the waterfront, whereas we say the Maritime Union has proven its reform bona fides with the recent agreement on shipping. The government has made secret agreements with the employer to use taxpayers' money for redundancy payouts which, as we pointed out in question time today, they refused to do for Cobar and Woodlawn miners.

The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, has been consistently on the job trying to stiffen the spine of Patricks. This is a grubby little plan hatched by Mr Reith, the same Mr Reith who sought and received a substantial discount on his luxury apartment in the Domain building, courtesy of Hudson Conway; the same Mr Reith who not only did that, but boasted about it. What would Penthouse Pete know about real Australian workers and real Australian workers' families?

We say that this is a cowardly and hypocritical strategy that has been pursued by the Howard government in the full knowledge that the real losers here will be all Australians, in the full knowledge that the Australian economy will suffer irreparable damage as a result of the government's policies.
Senator Ferguson interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI do not believeâand we have seen plenty of evidence of this todayâthat Australians will stand up and support a whole work force being sacked because they are a members of a legal union. I reckon you have misread this one, Senator Ferguson, and Australia will not stand for the economy being jeopardised for base political purposes. There is no doubt that today the gutter politics of this government are on display for all Australians to see. (Time expired)

âI also rise to take note of the answer given by Senator Hill. What a great week the MUA has had on the waterfront. Senator Faulkner describes these people as real Australian workers. Well, what a great job they have done for Australia this week. They have denied the free passage of shipping to P&C Stevedores, they have broken and bankrupted Patricks. Industrial warfare on the waterfront has cost Patricks $56 million. In doing so, these `real Australian workers' have sold out their familiesâtheir wives and their children. Thank goodness this government has put in a safety net loan provision to allow those families to continue, despite the disgraceful and irresponsible behaviour of those great Australian workers.

speech.para: The waterfront is locked in the 1950s, and the wharfies belong with them. Their industrial practices go with Morphy Richards toastersâremember the toasters that Paul Keating uses?âthe FJ Holdens, the Malvern Star bicyclesâ

talk.start.para: âAnd the Hills hoists.

âAnd the Hills hoists. A couple of weeks ago I met with a delegation of wharfies from Webb Dock in my office. They subsequently gave me a PR kit, which described their campaign for justice on the waterfront. Isn't it interesting that the cover of this PR kit shows half a ship, half a truck and a set of broken-down waterfront piles? What a joke.

speech.para: I suggest that those opposite consider for a moment the following comments that were made in relation to an industrial relations dispute when union officials compared farmers with the thugs and hooligans who supported Adolf Hitler and fascism in Germany. These were not the words from last night's press conference. They were the words used to describe the very first time the farmers decided that they were going to get their product out of this country as efficiently and effectively as the customers wanted. It was 20 years ago this week. It was the meatworkers, and the waterfront workers have learnt nothing from the experience, from the loss at that time. They subsequently lost live sheep, they lost Mudginberri and they will lose this dispute.
We have heard a lot today and we heard a couple of days ago as well that Bob Hawke was going to be brought in to solve the problems on the waterfront.
Senator O'Brien interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âHere is what Bob Hawke had to say when he talked about that last great dispute involving the Labor Partyâthe pilots dispute. I ask you, Senator O'Brien, to take note of this when you call this man in to help you on the waterfront. He said, `My message to them is that they will cop every instrument of punishing retribution and reaction that the operators bring against them. It's a different game this time, boys. It's war. They are exceptionally greedy.'

speech.para: But before you bring in the old Silver Bodgie to mediate, I draw to your attention that in the waterfront PR kit that was delivered to my office there was a list of names of people throughout the world and at home who care and who support `our stand against paramilitary personnel taking over Australian ports'. The first person is Archbishop Tutu. I am not quite sure how well briefed he was but when you are considering bringing in the old Silver Bodgie himself perhaps you should warn him that he will need to declare a conflict of interest, because, on the list of people throughout the world who care about this dispute and `support our stand against paramilitary personnel taking over the waterfront ports, are two names that might be of interest to him. The first is Hazel Hawke and the second is Blanche D'Alpuget, surely a very unfortunate conflict of interest for that great mediator, the former Prime Minister himself. There is absolutely no doubt that this waterfront dispute has gone on too long. It has broken the Patrick company and, if allowed to continue, it would break Australia. Thank goodness Cheryl Kernot and the Democrats saw the light. They understood that the waterfront has to work and they delivered. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âLast night just before midnight Patrick Stevedores sacked 1,400 dock workers in 17 docks around Australia. They did so with armed guards and with dogs on leashes and at a time which denied these workers access to their Easter leave entitlements. They did so expressly because the workers are union members and therefore the action was in breach of the act that this government put through this parliament. They did so during an industrial dispute and therefore directly in breach of this act. And they did so at a time which infringed the ILO articles of freedom of association. In other words, Patricks have acted illegally. Not only have they acted craftily, stealthily and sneakily; they have also acted illegally. That needs to be clear and on the record. I believe that when this matter goes to court that will be found.

speech.para: The trouble is that this government is hand in glove with them: it was at Cairns last year when it tried to interfere with waterfront reform, it was when it sponsored the training in Dubai of commandos to replace waterside workers and it was at Webb dock. It was hand in glove with them at every step of the way. This government is equally as culpable as Patricks and ought equally be held up before the courts because of its breach of its own laws, and the minister should be dealt with accordingly. They are the certain facts in this matter.
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSomeone has interjected `conspiracy'. That is an appropriate description of what has happened. Let me say a couple of things about this dispute. The first thing is that overnight and instantly, after it heard of this dismissal just before midnight, the government decided that it would get up a bill which is now introduced into the House of Representativesâthe fastest piece of legislation ever to be framed in the history of the Commonwealth of Australia. It is a bill which imposes a tax of $6 per car that is moved across the waterfront and $12 per containerâjust what we need for Australia's export industries. At a time in which the Asian economic crisis is hurting our export market, we are going to impose a new tax on the export industry. Why are we going to impose it? This government is going to try to impose it in order to cover its duplicity in this event, to pay out those waterside workers, if they will accept it, and to rescue Patricks. This is an unwarranted use of taxpayers' money for the government to employ in the event of an industrial dispute in order to buy their way through this dispute.

speech.para: In the case of waterfront reform, there are two great lies that are propounded by the government. The first great lie goes to what is the extent of the issues on the Australian waterfront front. Of all the cargoes movedâ

talk.start.para: âOn a point of order, Madam Deputy President: this senator was requested, during question time, to withdraw I think on four separate occasions, on three of those occasions for using the words `liar' or `lies'. When he suggests that the government lies, he makes that imputation against every single government member of the House of Representatives and of the Senate. He should withdraw that. I suggest: five times and you're out.

âSenator Cook, if you make it clear that you are not imputing that word to an individual member of parliament, then it is not unparliamentary, but if you are imputing it to a member of parliamentâ

âMadam Deputy President, I said that this government propounds two great lies; that is, the government as a collective. If the senator wants to take it personally, that is his lookout. I am in order, I submit.

âOn a point of order, Madam Deputy President: there have been previous rulings in this place that you cannot hide behind saying, `You mob over there are liars.' That is just as much an affront as saying, `A particular senator over there is a liar.' They have been the rulings in this place for some time and I would ask you to abide by those rulings.
âThat ruling is correct. If Senator Cook wishes to continue to use the word, he has to make it very clear that he is not referring in any way toâ
âWithdraw!
âSenator Ferris, I am in the middle of giving a ruling. I would appreciate silence. Senator Cook has to make it clear that he is not imputing any reflection upon any member in either house.
âThank you, Madam Deputy President. There are two great lies in this event. One lie is about waterfront reform.
âThe other lie is you.
âI beg your pardon?
âYou heard.
âSenator Ferguson, please withdraw that.
âMadam Deputy President, I understood, as Senator Cook was using the word, that it has become commonplace use in the chamber.
âSenator Ferguson, withdraw unconditionally and without additional comment. You were referring directly to an individual.
âMadam Deputy President, I was just attempting to withdraw unreservedly and you would not let me. I was just saying that the word seems to be freely used.
âThank you. That is all you need to withdraw.

âThank you. Ninety per cent of goods that cross Australian wharves are bulk commodities and are shifted in the bulk trade. In the bulk trade, Australia is at world's best practice. That is not my view; that is the view of the Bureau of Industry Economics which did a study on this matter in 1995âworld's best practice for 90 per cent of the goods across the waterfront. The other 10 per cent of the goods across the waterfront are in containers. At that level we have 20, or thereabouts, container movements per hour. That is not world's best practice, but it is damn close to it if you compare like with like. You cannot compare Australian ports with Rotterdam or Singapore, which are the world's best practice, because of the bulk movement of containers in those ports.

speech.para: Let us get these facts right. The waterfront in Australia, 90 per cent of the time, is world's best practice efficient and for the other 10 per cent it is in the appropriate order where our ports sit if you compare apples with apples.

talk.start.para: âKeep it honest.
âOrder on my right.

âThat is the honest truth. To refer you to the Bureau of Industry Economics, it is not a fact that you want to refer to in this dispute because it does not suit your convenience. I conclude on this. The way you get waterfront reformâand waterfront reform and efficiency, so that the exporters get paid better, is necessary in this countryâis not by confrontation with the waterfront; it is by cooperation and working with people on constructive ways of reform. You want to bring industrial muscle, fines and commandos to use against waterside workers, but that won't work. (Time expired)

âNothing demonstrates more than what we have just heard from Senator Cook the sort of problem that we have in reforming the Australian waterfront because the opposition simply refuses to acknowledge the problem. Unlike the opposition, the Australian community are all too well aware of the problem on the Australian waterfront and they are absolutely fed up with the hooliganism of the MUA. That is why they are supporting the reform process that this government has put in place. Senator Cook said, `You must cooperate with the union.' He is walking out now, he does not want to hear the truth. Sit down and listen.

âCould I take a point of order, Madam Deputy President? I have just been accused of not wanting to hear the truth. I have just made some remarks which I referenced to an independent source. That is the truth, and the sort of thing that we are hearing now is not the truth. I am quite happy to walk out on that.
âThere is no point of order.

âSenator Cook, as I was saying, encourages cooperation with the unions as the means to solve the problem and avoids a confrontation. But, Senator Cook, as you walk out, who is responsible for the confrontation? None other than John Coombs and the MUA. It is they who confronted the waterfront companies, the stevedoring companies, which are seeking relevant and appropriate reform. They were seeking to break Patricks because Patricks dared to challenge the inefficiencies as a result of the cosy monopoly that was previously enjoyed by the wharfies.

speech.para: They were singled out by the Maritime Union and subjected to punitive strike action. That cost that company $56 million. So it is no wonder they had to make their employees redundant when they suffered that massive cost. And of course the MUA made it very clear that any attempt to reform the waterfront would `involve massive industry disputation'âa test of wills. Well, there has been a test of wills, and the MUA lost the test of wills. They lost the test of wills because, as I said, the Australian community generally recognise and support the need for improved efficiency on the Australian waterfront. Australia, as an island nation, an island continent, is absolutely dependent on our waterfront and our sea transport for the export of our wealth earning goods. We cannot survive without it.

On a value for money basis, in a recent survey it was found that Australia's wharfies ensured that Australia's ports were ranked at the bottom of the list. Sadly, as a South Australian senator, I have to say that Adelaide was the worst of all in terms of value for money. Adelaide rates 18 out of the 18 ports surveyed around the world. Our crane rates are below international standards at 18.3 lifts per hour. A number of ports around the world achieve lifts of 30 per hour. What the government is seeking as a benchmark is 25 lifts per hour, a quite modest goal in relation to international standards. It is a modest benchmark to establish, yet the unions are objecting to lifting the rate from the current 18.3.

Other problems with efficiency on the waterfront include the temporary or permanent disability of about 10 per cent of the work forceâmuch higher than in any other industry. Of course, when it comes to working days lost because of industrial action, in 1996, 1,130 working days were lost per 1,000 employeesâwell above that of any other industry.

The reason for that is because of all the rorts that are continuing on the waterfront. We heard about the stripper rort where the rate of 10.4 containers an hour on the first shift suddenly lifted to 29.7 containers an hour when they were told they could knock off after they finished to go to the stripper show down at the local pub. We know about the airconditioning rort where, even though the cabs of the equipment have airconditioning, the wharfies will not work if the outside temperature is more than 39 degrees. There is the safety card rort. There is the car loading rort where five wharfies are required to load a car. And so the rorts go on.

And the Labor Party has the gall to come in here and criticise the employers. They do that because of their own failed WIRA pro cess when they were in office. When it came to waterfront reform, the Labor Party were on one long smoko when they were in government. They spent some $430 million of taxpayers' moneyâ

talk.start.para: âHow much?

âSome $430 million of taxpayers' money, Senator Abetz, and achieved nothing in terms of reform. There was some temporary improvement but, as soon as the government removed the pressure, the reform process finished and we slipped back to the bad old ways, the rorts and the over-manning.

speech.para: The Interstate Commission said exactly that at the outset of that reform process. It said, `There is a tendency for matters to improve considerably while they are under investigation, but to lapse once the pressure is removed.' Labor removed the pressure; we are keeping the pressure on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWhat a spectacle we were treated to this morning. We were awakened to the news on all of the media that Reith's raiders had reclaimed the waterfront. Reith's white shirts had moved in in the dead of night with vicious dogs, taken over the waterfront and secured Patricks from those terrible wharfies. There was a real threat to our whole community.

speech.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt is not funny.

âIt is not funny; it is deadly serious. There are 1,400 families around this country that have been made Howard's Easter bunnies by your actions. You do not give a damn about the workers of this country, and you never have. You are only concerned with your mates at the big end of town.

speech.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Campbell, would you please address the chair, and would those interjecting on my right please cease.

âThe reality, Madam Deputy President, is that what occurred this morning has been the culmina tion of what has been in planning for the past 18 months. And it has nothing to do with efficiency on the waterfront; it has nothing to do with improving productivity on the waterfront.

speech.para: This mob came to power in March 1996 with this hidden agenda of crushing the Waterside Workers Federation, or the Maritime Union of Australia as it is now known. That was the secret agenda developed by ACIL through the secret consultancy reports that they have refused to make public. That is what the Cairns waterfront dispute was all about. That was the first trial run, and it was a dismal failure. That is what Dubai was all about. It was about trying to set up the scabs who were going to move in on the maritime workers. That is what Webb Dock was all about.

Anybody here who seriously believes that the PCS and the National Farmers Federation were serious about moving one container across the waterfront at Webb Dock has rocks in their head. They believe in fairies at the bottom of the garden. It was a deliberate set-up to position the union, to put them into court and to try and break them financially. That is what the agenda at Webb Dock was all about. That is what they were on about. They were trying to put them in a position where they breached the laws of this country so that they would be penalised severely for it.

But what do we have now? The laws of the country are being broken by an employer with the complicity of the government. It is not only that the laws of the country are being broken with the complicity of the government; the government is providing financial support, taxpayers' money, in order to back up the actions that have occurred on the waterfront.

talk.start.para: âHe believes itâthat's the trouble.

âLet me tell you something, Senator Abetz, do not put your cue in the rack yet. Do not think that this dispute is over. Do not think that just because the white shirts of Peter Reith are on the waterfront today that they will stay there. Don't you think for one minute this dispute will be over in five minutes, because I can assure you, through long experience, that it will not. I actually worked on the waterfrontâI worked on the Sydney waterfront and I worked on the Melbourne waterfrontâand I know a little bit about its history.

speech.para: One thing the people on that side of the chamber cannot stomach and the reason they are so vicious in relation to that union is that the union nicknamed the founder of the Liberal Party `Pig Iron Bob'. They found him out, they found out what the game was, and the Liberal Party have never forgiven them for it. The Liberal Party have never forgiven the wharfies for nicknaming Menzies `Pig Iron Bob'.

Look at the agenda of the Liberal Party since it has been in government. It has not changedâonly the players have changed. When the Liberal Party came to power in 1975, what did Malcolm Fraser do? He did two things. Firstly, he put a provision in the act for conscientious objection and, secondly, the Liberal Party went out and stirred up people all around the country to stand up and to leave unions. They created disputes all over the place. Then the Liberal Party put in place an industrial relations bureauâFraser's industrial relations police. What for? Not to make the rules of the industrial relations game equal but to skew them in favour of the employer. That is what their agenda was.

What happened in 1996? Exactly the same. The government came in and introduced industrial relations laws. Peter Reith, the pretender Prime Minister in the other place, said, `We're introducing these laws because it should be up to the players in industrial relations to solve the problem. Let them get out there and do it themselves.' What happened? There is a blue on the waterfront, a dispute on the waterfront, and the first thing the government does is move in on the side of the employer. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âWell, Senator George Campbell, spoken like a true union organiser. That is, of course, what you were, weren't you? Were you on the wharfies union? It was your revered former leader Mr Keating who accused you of having 100,000 dead men around your neck. Senator George Campbell is in the union. He is a union organiser and he cannot look after the real workers. The wharfies union is the group that puts the real workers out of work.

speech.para: I heard Senator George Campbell talk about scabs. We know what scabs are: scabs are those people who bring in the troops or bring in overseas workers to break a union strike. Who did that in recent history? The opposition well knows because it was their revered leader Bob Hawke who brought in the troops to break a strike. Before that, the last major Labor Prime Minister, Mr Chifley, also brought in the troops to break a union strike. Do not talk about us being scabs. In Australian history, only the Labor Party has ever brought in troops to break a union strike. What is more, they brought in foreign workers to put Australian workers out of a job. That is the record of the Australian Labor Party.

There has been a lot of whingeing and carrying on from the other side about what they say is unfair industrial relations law. I just cannot work out why they say this because it was the star recruit of the Labor Party, Ms Cheryl Kernot, the Australian Labor Party candidate for Dickson, who ensured that this legislation was passed. Now they are complaining about it. If the opposition did not like the laws that Ms Kernot brought in, why did they endorse her as the Labor candidate for Dickson? You cannot have it both ways: either the legislation is right because a star Labor candidate ensured that we passed it orâ

talk.start.para: âFading star.

âThat is rightâa fading star. I fear for a lot of the workers in Australia. They are people who are looked after by the likes of Senator George Campbell. The former Labor leader Paul Keating said of Senator George Campbell that he had 100,000 dead men around his neck. Mr Keating at least knew that union organisers, like the group that we have opposite in the Senate, are not there in the best interests of the workers. They are only interested in their own position and in manipulating their political puppetsâthe politicians in the Labor Party.

speech.para: I am forever sorry, as I know all genuine Labor people are, that a Labor Prime Minister had to bring in overseas workers to break a strike. He not only brought in overseas workers but he also brought in the troops. Remember the air force? They were very reluctant starters, I might say. But the air force were ordered to come in to break a strike of Australian workers. Why didn't the then government want to support that union? Was it because they were highly paid people? Is that why the then government did not want to support them? What about the wharfies? The wharfies get $80,000 on averageâa little bit more than the average Australian worker. There would not be many airline pilots who would get that particular pay. Yet the Labor Party brought in overseas workers to break that strike. It was a Labor Prime Minister, supported by all those who happened to be over on that side at that time. Not one of those people raised their voice to stop overseas scabs and the troops being brought in to break that union's strike.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I take a point of order. My point of order is that Senator Ian Macdonald is misleading the chamber. He is referring to an incident some years ago which, at the time, had the wholehearted support of the then opposition. It was when the commercial airline pilots resigned; there was no strike. Senator Ian Macdonald travelled on the RAAF aircraft.
âOrder! Senator McKiernan, there is no point of order.

âI raise a point of order, Madam Deputy President. If Senator McKiernan can stand for two minutes to make a point of order which has no relevance whatsoever to what is being said, and you do not sit him down, perhaps while he is on his feet he could explain why the country he left can move twice as many containers as the country he has come to.
âSenator Ferguson, there is no point of order.

âMadam Deputy President, I want to take Senator McKiernan's point because I never travelled on a plane that was driven by strikebreakersâmainly because I was not in parliament at the timeâbut Senator McKiernan did. And Senator Ray, were you the defence minister who ordered those troops in to break the strike? You were the defence minister and you ordered the troops in. What a disgrace.
âNo, I was not.
âOh, you weren't the defence minister. I am sorry. You weren't the defence minister.

speech.para: Senator Robert Ray interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOh, you were the immigration Minister. You brought in the foreign workers. You didn't send the troops in; you allowed the foreign workers in.
âOrder! The time for the debate has expired.
âA petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate, decisions by the Howard Government affecting the price and availability of medicines.

speech.para: That the Senateâ
