So I will put that on notice at this stage. I do not think the government would have a problem with it because of its consistency.
âWe will need it in writing because the clerks are having trouble finding out exactly where it needs to be.
âI will get someone to write it down, but people are on notice so we can come back to it straight after Senator Harradine.
âSenator Harradine, do you want to move your replacement amendment RN4 now? Senator Bolkus was just giving notice of his amendment.
âI seek your guidance, Mr Temporary Chairman. This is, in effect, a recommittal.
âMy advice is that your amendment was negatived, Senator Harradine, so you are quite entitled to introduce it as a replacement amendment.

âThank you. Honourable senators will recall the debate that took place on the registration test and my attempt to have the registration test expanded so that those persons who would not qualify under the guidelines established by the government in its amendment to the legislation would be eligible to obtain registration. I will read to the committee this amendment which is to add to the registration test provisions paragraph 11. I move:

speech.para: (RN4) Schedule 2, item 63, page 206 (after line 28), at the end of section l90B, add:

(11) For the purposes of the operation of paragraph (7)(b), a reference to a member of the native title claim group will be taken to include a reference to a parent of a member of the native title claim group who previously had, and would reasonably have been expected during his or her life to have continued to have, a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters but for things done (other than the creation of an interest in relation to land or waters) by:
(a) the Crown in any capacity; or
(b) a statutory authority of the Crown in any capacity; or
(c) any other person.

This was specifically designed to cover the `stolen generation' and to cover those indigenous persons and groups who were locked out by pastoralists or by any other means; in other words, it is the locked gate and stolen generation amendment. I will not go over the arguments that I advanced on the last occasion in support of this amendment. I am grateful for the support of the opposition at that time. The amendment was, however, lost, and I put it to the committee again in the hope that the committee might see its way clear on this occasion, at this late stage, to support the amendment.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition does support this amendment. I think most of us have actually been haunted by the injustice that has flowed from the first time we debated and decided on the registration test. I, for one, have been trying to grapple, in the last 48 hours or so, with how in fact do we try to overcome the fact that, in doing what we did a couple of days ago, we have actually done a huge injustice to at least one generation of Aboriginal people. The law, as it would now operate if this bill was proclaimed, would provide for a registration test that would involve a registrar being satisfied that the factual basis on which it was asserted that the native title rights and interests claim is sufficient to supportâand I stress those words `sufficient to support', as opposed to prima facieâa contention that at least one member of the claimant group currently had, or previously had, a traditional physical connection with the land or previously had, and would reasonably be expected currently to have, a traditional physical connection with the land but for the actions of the Crown, statutory authority or another person.

speech.para: This new alternative is the one we need to focus on because it is not a stolen generation clause, because it requires that persons must have previously have had a traditional physical connection with the land before they can pursue their interests now. It is a contemporary locked gates clause in that it only applies to people who are currently locked out but who also previously had a physical connection to the land. That is not the registration test that this Senate agreed to in December 1997. We do not have to revisit the whole heated debate that we had the other day, but let us remember that this is not the test that we agreed to in 1997 nor of course is Senator Harradine's amendment. But what Senator Harradine does do in his amendment is ensure that the stolen generations can return to the land and have some rights under the Native Title Act.

As I said yesterday, without going through the whole debate again, in practical terms, this provision would ensure that most of those, if not all, who would qualify under Justice Brennan's test in Mabo would be able to get in through this particular provision. I said yesterday that it is not our preferred one, but it goes a long way to meeting our preferred one. But let us remember that without it we will leave this debate denying particularly the stolen generation's justice.

talk.start.para: âI want to ask a question of Senator Harradine in relation to this amendment. Its wording is quite different from the amendment moved the first time. Can Senator Harradine explain what the difference is and why there is a difference in the wording?
âI do not have the previous amendment in front of me, but I am advised that the changes in the wording were of a technical nature and do not alter the purpose of the previous amendment.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âBefore lunch today the government had received Senate support for its position on two of the four critical areas that we had identified as fundamental to the government's bill. After lunch we lost one of them when the sunset clause was recommitted and thrown out. If the Greens support this proposition, then it looks like after dinner we will lose the only remaining one of the four on which the Senate had supported the government's position. So the bill would therefore come out of the Senate without the government having received support on any of the four really critical areas for us.

speech.para: I can only restate what I said before on the question of the registration test. We think that for the registration test to operate effectivelyâparticularly if in the case of the opposition parties' premise the right to negotiate is going to apply across 79 per cent of Australiaâit has to be a good test. This amendment takes you back to a situation where, even though not one member of the claim group has ever had any connection to the land claimed, the claim can still be registered and give the claimants access to the statutory right to negotiate. That is one reason for our opposition to this. There is also the fact that we do not think a proposition like this can be made workable. I do not know how registrars would be meant to satisfy themselves on this. Parents who may well not be alive being taken account of in determining the question of physical connection seems to us impractical as well as so watering down the registration test as to reduce its effectiveness quite seriously and considerably.

talk.start.para: âThe reason I asked the question of Senator Harradine earlier on in relation to the wording is that, as Senator Harradine is aware, the amendment did not actually work last time. Senator Harradine has just told me that the amendment does basically the same as it did last time. If that is case, my advice was that there were problems within the actual bill that made this very difficult to amend in this way. Can you explain that it does not do the same thing that it did last time in some other complex way?

âCould I just explain that the previous draft required the parent to `currently' have the connection. In the case of a deceased parent that could not be possible. This amendment caters for that situation.

âClearly, we are all very tired, but what we are doing, despite what Senator Bolkus said, is reopening the whole debate that we hadâI cannot remember whenâsome time ago. I am sorry, but that is what we are doing. And there is no way that, unless we have that debate, the Democrats could ever accept this.

speech.para: Senator Minchin has been very honest, and I am glad about that. I do not know whether `honest' is the right word but he has certainly been very frank, and he always isâI think I could add `honest', because I can be generous at this time of night. And he has said that the government will not accept this amendment either. So what are we doing? The bill is going to be laid aside by the House of Representatives in a few hours time, so what is this achieving? We did not reopen the debateâlet me point that outâbut we certainly are going to have it, because we are not going to be forced again to simply vote on an amendment which is very much not a second or third best. Actually, it is about a fourth best if you add up the number of amendments which are possible in this debate.

I am listening to Senator Harradine; I am listening to the government; I am listening to Senator Bolkus. But I have to say to you that we are not convinced at this stage that we should vote for this particular amendment. Even though I think it explains far better what Senator Harradine was attempting to do, it does not change the principle. The principle that we have objected to all along and which we debated at great length not only two nights ago but before Christmas is that a simple physical connection test, whether you take it back one generation or not, is totally inadequate.

What would have been more helpful is for Senator Harradine to bring back either the Indigenous Working Group amendment or the Labor amendment, both of which we supported, because that would have given us some real options. It would have enabled us to really make some progress. But why would we reopen a bill that the government is going to rejectâSenator Harradine's amendment is going to be rejected by the governmentâfor hardly any gain but for a lot more pain again, I can tell you? This is the problem. Senator Margetts may like to add to my remarks.

talk.start.para: âHonourable senators may have noticed that sheet 957 has been circulated, and I will be asking for recommittal in relation to the registration test. In a very short time you will see another sheet as well. Sheet 957 is basically re-putting the Greens (WA)-Democrats amendments of last time, with some slight variation.

speech.para: What you will see very soon is an amendment, in the name of the Greens and the Democrats, that last time was moved by the ALP. As Senator Woodley suggests, it was not us who reopened this debate. If we are going to open it, we should in fairness provide the option of choices again. Senator Bolkus has indicated that he has had some time to repent, so perhaps the repentance might go so far as to relook at his own amendment. I also would suggest that other senators in the place might consider it. I am sure Senator Bolkus will be prepared to support what is, in fact, his own amendment, but, of course, we need more than Senator Bolkus.

Given that the government is clearly indicating that it is not going to move any further with the bill in the form that the Senate has carefully dealt with it, I think it would be a positive, very conciliatory and very important note on which to conclude the debate to heed the concerns of the National Indigenous Working Group, which made some strong statements today in the media and in public, and to look very carefully at rejecting the concept that a physical connection test is necessary for registration. So we will have two choices very soon. By the time we have voted on Senator Harradine's amendment, which I have to say I am still unable to support, we will have the new amendment 1 on sheet 969 that we hope the Senate will permit us to deal with again.

talk.start.para: âAt the instigation of Senator Harradine, we are faced with a recommittal of all three options and a vote on those. So we do get an opportunity to get back to where we were in December last yearâno halfway house, no little bit for one generation and, as Senator Bolkus described Senator Harradine's option, no second preference. This is not the preferred one, but let us get back to where we were in December last year so that we give an opportunity to all those people who have a real spiritual and cultural connection with their land to be able to approach the registrar.

speech.para: I want to say a word of commendation for the people who are working hard in our offices. They have been so swift in this situation where the plan was to bring in the Harradine option and leave us to vote on thatâtake it or leave itâbut they have given us back the strong options as well in a matter of minutes. The test here, of course, will come on to Senator Harradine in a little while to see if, with the Labor Party, the Greens and the Democrats, he stands strong on the position that we had in December last year. I am not going to call this an ambush move at the end of the committee, but I am going to say that it was a very fast response from the offices of the Greens and Democrats. It gives us the proper opportunity that we should have to vote on the three amendments.

Like Senator Woodley and Senator Margetts, I will not be supporting the weak, in the middle option that will be voted on first. We will be standing for the strong options, including the ALP's own option that was adopted by the Senate last year. I do not know why this has come right at the end. Maybe Senator Bolkus gave the hint when he said they have been haunted by the failure to stand on the ground where they stood in December last year. For one thing, I will thank Senator Harradine for giving the opposition and himself the opportunity to be rid of the ghost, to go back to where they were in December last year, to hold their ground and to make sure that the strong amendment here is the one that we adopt.

talk.start.para: âWe have to face the facts here. The position is this: at the time the registration test was being put to the chamber, there was a likelihoodâI will put it at that levelâthat there would be an outcome which would be reasonable, fair, just and honourable. That being so, it was incumbent upon the chamber, I believe, at that stage to look carefully at what the government was proposing in respect of a threshold test which would enable only genuine native title claimants to get registered. It has to be clearly borne in mind that this deals with only one of the tracks that is available in the legislation for the consideration of native title claims. There have been a number of comments made subsequently about that, and I will deal with those in a moment.

speech.para: Having regard to that, it was, I believe, incumbent on the chamber to examine as it did what was being said in the debate at that time by the government in respect of its own registration test. I am not going to canvass all of those arguments that took place on the last occasion. I do not think that would be proper at this time of the night. The reasons that were advanced by Senator Minchin on behalf of the government and the calls that have been made on a number of us to have a threshold test which would enable the registrar to revisit a number of the claims is believed by every stakeholder, including the indigenous people and the indigenous leadership, to be bogus and almost fraudulent.

That is what we were faced with, and what we are still faced with. If we are fair dinkum about this situation, that is what we are faced with even now. I have heard what the government has said. It may well be that the Senate on this occasion may adopt an attitude which was different to the last occasion.

The position was that the government's test was then supported. In my view, it was most inadequate in that it did not cover the stolen generation and those who suffered as a result of the locked gates policy of certain pastoral leaseholders.

That view was also taken by the opposition, and the opposition supported the amendment that I put forward. It was at that stage that negotiations were taking place, which unfortunately are no longer taking place. That is a most unfortunate situation. But the Greens and the Democrats voted against my amendmentâin other words, they voted against the locked gates and stolen generation persons.

I suppose one can say that they were not to know what stage the discussions had reached. They were not to know that it was possible to get something out of the situation with which we were faced. But I had to deal with this matter at a level of responsibility knowing what I did at that particular stage. I do not intend to deal with it in any other wayâwhether I knew or whether I did not know. But that was the situation.

I moved this amendment so as to cater for those two groups of people and did not agree with the test which the Greens and Democrats were talking about which would not really deal with the problem that was identified by certain of the leaders of the indigenous people as well as by all of the other stakeholders, et cetera. But, even with the support of the opposition, that amendment of mine was defeated and we were left with the threshold test of the government. I appeal to the committee to support this amendment.

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Harradine for his contribution. I, too, would like a fair, just and honourable outcome from this debate. I would suggest to the Senate that a fair, just and honourable outcome for indigenous people would be to support the position that they themselves have put. Fortunately, because Senator Harradine has recommitted this, we have the opportunity to do that. I am sure that, if Senator Harradine's amendment is not successful, the Labor Party and Senator Harradine will have the opportunity to vote for eitherâwe do not mind whichâthe Indigenous Working Group's amendment, which we will put, or the Labor Party's amendment. The Labor Party's amendment is not as good as the Indigenous Working Group amendment, but we believe that both of those are a great distance away from either the government's position or Senator Harradine's amendment.

speech.para: So there will be an opportunity for a fair, just and honourable outcome from this because it has been recommitted and we now have the choice of doing this in the order that it should have been done in fact last time we voted. We will have the opportunity now of voting either for the ALP's amendment or for the indigenous working group amendment if Senator Harradine's amendment is defeated. If the Senate votes for either of those, that certainly will be a fair, just and honourable outcome.

talk.start.para: âAs I said earlier, this has been a debate which has rolled from one side to another. We have always come to this debate knowing that we had only 28 votes to protect and defend native title interests and to get a balanced outcome and to get certainty. We always had to build on those 28 votes to get to 38. Of course, part of that process has been to try to work out positions that could get support in this place.

speech.para: As I and Senator Harradine said earlier, there has been an enormous pressure on people in this chamber to try to overcome the prospect of a double dissolution based on race. We do have a responsibility as parliamentarians to ensure that the society that we live in is harmonious in its coexistence with each other. I for one have been able to feel the pressure, indirectly I must say, through a whole host of people who have been to see Senator Harradine. I have been able to feel that pressure reverberating into their offices, their aspirations, and into our offices as well. I have to say that no-one should consistently be subjected to that sort of pressure, as Senator Harradine has.

In terms of time, this debate gives a new definition to the word `marathon'. When we combine this process this time with the previous debate, we find the parliament has spent some 87 hours and 42 minutes on this native title bill. The committee stage has been some almost 70 hours of that. That is an enormous continuation of pressure. For those who are on the parliamentary committees concernedâtwo Senate legal and constitutional committees and the Joint Committee on Native Titleâit has been the best part of our lives. For Senator Harradine I think it has been as well.

But, no matter how much people tried to compromise, they were met with a brick wall from the government. Eighty per cent, 85 per cent, 90 per cent of the 10-point plan through this parliament but the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), still barricaded in his bunker, still digs in and says, `I want all. To the rest of you'âstakeholders, indigenous Australians, taxpayers and those who will become the victims of a race debateâ`I really don't care because I want my 10-point plan.' How childish. How obdurate.

At the end of this debate what I think the Senate has to contend with is whether, now that all prospects of compromise are over, it is opportune for us to actually go back and say, `We tried in respect of the registration testâan important sticking point. We tried. But what this Senate has come up with is just not good enough.' You cannot leave this debate with the injustice of the stolen generations being deprived of access to their lands. You cannot leave this debate with people who have been locked out over the decades not having access. It is a sad reflection on this government that no-one expects the government to move in the interest of justice. No-one expects justice from the government; so it is up to us.

I will seek leave of the Senate to recommit my amendment N36, which was the amendment that was passed by the Senate last year and which provides for the three tests of access in the alternative and provides explicitly for the words of Justice Brennan as one of the three legs. I will seek leave to recommit that particular amendment. Now that all prospects of a compromise with the Prime Minister are out the window, I hope the Senate at least will give a commitment to justice for those who would be unfairly deprived. I hope that, in those circumstances, not only will the Greens and the Democrats support it but also Senator Harradine will find it attractive now. We have tried to compromise. It takes two to tango, and the government has not been with us. In those circumstances, let us not deny access to those who should have a just access to the land.

talk.start.para: âWe have heard two things in the last half hour or so. The first is that the series of amendments which came in which gave ground from last December were in fact motivated by communications with the government at the highest levelâI would write the words `Prime Minister' in there. The incentive was given to come further and further. But, even at the end of the day, that was not far enough. That is what we suspected all along. We were not told it. Because we were not told it and could not understand why these middle grounds kept being put forward by Senator Harradine or the ALP, we stood our groundâand it has been the right thing to do.

speech.para: Tonight, when Senator Harradine came back with his amendment, the only thing for us to do was to bring back the strong amendments. I am pleased to see that, because of the Democrat and Greens' holding of the ground, the ALP is now saying, `We will take from the Greens, who have brought this amendment back, our amendment and put it forward ourselves.' That is something they will find we will be supporting. It is where we should have been last Monday night and it is certainly where we should end up tonight.
Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to recommit opposition amendment N36.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI have spoken to it. I move:

speech.para: (N36) Schedule 2, item 63, page 205 (line 22) to page 206 (line 28), omit subsections (5) to (10), substitute:

para.inline: Registrar's satisfaction about the basis of the Application

speech.para: (5) The Registrar must be satisfied that:
(a) the factual basis on which it is asserted that the native title rights and interests claimed exist is sufficient to support the assertion and that it supports the following assertions:
(i) that the native title claim group have, and the predecessors of those persons had, an association with the area;
(ii) that there exist traditional laws acknowledged by, and traditional customs observed by, the native title claim group that give rise to the claim to native title rights and interests;
(iii) that the native title claim group has continued to hold the native title in accordance with those traditional law and customs; or
(b) at least one member of the native title claim group:
(i) currently has or previously had a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters covered by the application; or

(ii) would reasonably have been expected currently to have a traditional physical connection with any part of the land or waters but for things done (other than the creation of an interest in relation to land or waters) by the Crown in any capacity, a statutory authority of the Crown in any capacity or any other person.
(6) The Registrar must consider that, prima facie, at least some of the native title rights and interests claimed in the application can be established.

Note: If the claim is accepted for registration, the Registrar must, under paragraph 186(1)(g), enter on the Register of Native Title Claims details of only those claimed native title rights and interests that can, prima facie, be established. Only those rights and interests are taken into account for the purposes of subsection 31(2) (which deals with negotiation in good faith in a "right to negotiate" process) and subjection 39(1) (which deals with criteria for making arbitral body determinations in a "right to negotiate" process).

para.inline: No failure to comply with section 61A

speech.para: (7) The application and accompanying documents must not disclose, and the Registrar must not otherwise be aware, that, because of section 61A (which forbids the making of applications where there have been previous native title determinations or exclusive or non-exclusive possession acts) the application should not have been made.

(8) If the Registrar is considering placing reliance on material which is adverse to the interests of the claimant, or inconsistent with material supplied by the claimant, the claimant must be shown the material and given a reasonable opportunity to respond or supply further material.

para.inline: No extinguishment of native title to minerals etc.

speech.para: (9) The application and accompanying documents must not disclose, and the Registrar must not otherwise be aware, that to the extent that the native title rights and interests claimed consist of or include ownership of minerals, petroleum or gasâthe Crown in right of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory wholly owns the minerals, petroleum or gas.
Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: âWe need to recommit government amendment No. 73 so that Senator Bolkus can move his amendment N37.
âThere may not be an objection, but I think both Senator Minchin and I are a little confused as to what you are doing.
âWe are dealing with running sheet No. 17 revised 2 registration test. Senator Bolkus, we might seek your guidance. It is just a matter of whether or not you want to proceed with N37.
âI seek leave to recommit amendment N37.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: (N37) Schedule 2, item 63, subsection 190B(6), omit "some", substitute "one".

This is an associated amendment with the vote that we have just taken. It is an amendment to government amendment 73 and it amends 190B(6) such that native title claimants must only establish prima facie one rather than some native title rights. Given that native title claimants need only establish one right or interest to access the right to negotiate under the current act, the requirement that some rights be established is inconsistent with the other provisions of the act.
Amendment agreed to.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âMr Temporary Chairman, the Senate has amended the opposition amendment. The opposition's test is now N36 and 37 is, in effect, an amendment to the clause inserted by opposition amendment 36. I just want to make sure we know what has happened here.

speech.para: There is a little confusion. In effect, by recommitting N36 and agreeing to it, that effectively displaces our 73. So 73 disappears in effect. I do not know how that is done procedurally, but it has that effect. So this amendment is to 36.

talk.start.para: âI think it will disappear in the fullness of time, Minister. I might not have explained it too well but I am sure it will disappear. Is it correct to assume that the Greens WA and Democrats amendment on sheets 957 and 969 will not be proceeded with?
âI confirm that, Mr Chairman.
âSenator Bolkus, I am informed that you were foreshadowing a consequential amendment that is now no longer to be proceeded with.
âThe advisers have managed to inform us that inconsistency had been picked up in the mechanics of the Senate drafting and we do not need to proceed with it.

speech.para: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Minchin) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: âI wish to say a few things on this third reading, Madam Deputy President. For us on this side of the parliament, the conclusion of this debate marks a day of shame. There is no shame to non-government senators and stakeholders who have worked tirelessly and creatively towards an acceptable outcome; no shame to the thousands of Australians who have written, faxed and phoned urging a broadly acceptable solution to the dilemma visited on all of us by the Prime Minister; no shame to ANTA, which has blossomed over recent months, or its constituent groups and bodies; no shame to the indigenous people driven by despair to depart from this place before the conclusion of this debate, but bucketloads of shame to the divisive opportunists who have basically left us standing at the abyss staring at a double dissolutionâa future filled with doubt, discord and fear.

speech.para: This is the debate that we did not need to have this time around. This is a debate that we do not need to continue to have. We could have had some months of experience of an enacted, amended bill by now. We could have had validation. We could have been on the way to sorting out the backlog of claims before the courts and the tribunal. Last December, this Senate sent a clear message to the government. It said that, if we were to get a compromise acceptable to all the players in this debate, then the government had to give some ground on those four key sticking pointsâthe right to negotiate, the registration test, the sunset clause and the application of the Racial Discrimination Act.

For weeks, days and nights in the lead-up to this debate, all parties were involved in extensive negotiations with the government to try and find a way through. Indeed, up until even a few hours ago, Senator Harradine was trying his utmost to see if there was even the smallest glimmer of compromise on the part of this government on the most fundamental issue in the debate, the right to negotiate. But all efforts have been in vain.

I think Senator Harradine, like all senators in this place, continued his negotiation in the hope that we were dealing with someone who genuinely wanted to lead this nation towards an accommodation on the contentious issue of native titleâa person who, despite the many indications to the contrary that he has given over the last few years, really wants to bring Australians together to resolve our problems. But I think the evidence is that we were wrong. There was no hope. I regret to say I suppose there probably never wasâand only for one reason, I must say, unfortunately, because it is only the Prime Minister who wants an early election. He wants to use the wedge politics that got him elected in 1996 to divide and conquer our nation againâAustralian against Australian on the docks; Australian against Australian in the courts; Australian against Australian in the bush.

It was Dennis Shanahan, I think, who recently said that this Prime Minister has ignored the cooler heads in his cabinet. I must say, at the end of 87 hours of debating, arguing or whatever with Senator Minchin, I have come to the conclusion that Senator Minchin himself may well be one of those cooler heads who wants an outcome. Instead, the Prime Minister has turned to his gut instincts that have seen him let Australia down on social issues so many times in the past. We do not forget that it was the Prime Minister who was one of the leading opponents of sanctions against South Africa during the 1980s. We do not forget that it was this Prime Minister who spoke against the adoption of the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975. We do not forget that it was this Prime Minister who spoke out against Asian immigration in 1988. We must not forget also that it was this Prime Minister who led a party room revolt against John Hewson's plans to take a constructive approach to the debate on native title in 1993. What we cannot forget is that it was this Prime Minister who failed to stand up to the racist views of Pauline Hanson and who is yet to refuse her preferences.

We require leadership and we are not getting good leadership. It is not good leadership to take this nation to a deeply divisive double dissolution election based on race, an election which will divide black against white, city against country. It is not good leadership to act out of fear of Pauline Hanson.

It is interesting that the bushfire has been lit and, we see in the Bulletin poll this morning, the National Party vote in Queensland has gone down some 13 per cent and the One Nation vote stands at 13 per cent. The Nation al Party vote in Queensland has been halved by the bushfire that you have allowed to blow out of control. It is the National Party that could very well be the victims of the bushfire that they fanned.

Our concern, though, is that Australians will suffer. Farmers will suffer because they will not be given the certainty they deserve and which was theirs for the asking in the proclaimed bill last December. Stakeholders and miners will suffer because their ventures will be held up in the courts for decades to come and ordinary Australians will have to pay the bill. And our nation suffers in other ways. What is important is not what the international community thinks of us, it is how we think of ourselves and how we can live with ourselves.

I am one of those who thinks that there does not have to be an election based on this Senate amending, in minor part, this Native Title Amendment Bill. The government has got 90 per cent of what it wants. In respect of that, I think the government should now step back from the brink, take the bill, enact the bill, get on with government and let the nation lead a better future. If there is a double dissolution on this bill, there will not be a joint sitting of the parliament until early next year or late this year. You will be denying certainty to farmers, miners and stakeholders for a prolonged period. You could have given them certainty last December. For gross based political purposes you have been denying them that certainty for 12 months.

When this bill first came to the Senate I reminded the government of their covenant with the nation, the responsibility they took in accepting office, and the terms they inherited from the Keating government to continue to integrate the concept, expression and exercise of native title in the social and legal framework of this nation. That is still their challenge.

In closing, there are a few people I would like to thank because this has been a marathon effort. There have been some 87 hours of debate in the parliament: 56 or so hours last time and over 30 hours this time. I thank the Senate staff, Rosemary Laing, Kathleen Griffiths and Rosa Ferranda, and all the other staff of the Senate Table Office. I thank my colleagues Kim Beazley, Gareth Evans, Daryl Melham, Stephen Smith and Neil O'Keefe, who form the core group of our native title working group, a group that has worked extremely well together and, contrary to all the expectations and propaganda of the government, has worked cohesively together. It could not have got here without the Whip and the Deputy Whip in this place and the work that they have done.

In terms of advisers and support staff, I would like to thank Anna George, Sarah Crichton, Julia Clifford, Christine Evans, Chris McGrath, James Cullen and Nina Gerace. Of the other people, and there have been heaps of people who have helped in one way or another, there has been a group of lawyers who do not get paid the amount of money that lawyers working for the top end of Collins Street get paid. Their dedication, their application, their tenacity, their strength and their intelligence cannot be underrated. We have had people like John Basten QC and Ron Castan, Chris Athanisiou and Angus Frith who have made enormous contributions and who have worked extremely well under pressure. These are people who basically give more than they will ever get paid for.

In the adviser boxes, Simon Banks from my office, James Fitzgerald and Mike Megaw together have been able to plough through the work, put submissions to us and ensure that a constructive alternative has been put to the parliament and to the nation. I thank all of them. In closing I say, once again: step back from the brink, we do not need an election on this issue.

talk.start.para: âI, too, want to speak in the third reading debate tonight. A feature of this debate this time has been the changing and changed positions of all parties in this chamber apart from the government, sad to say. Although tonight I was going to be fairly critical of the ALP and Senator Harradine, I think the outcome we achieved in the last hour really makes me not want to do that.

speech.para: I have to say that we could have avoided some of that pain had we perhaps achieved the outcome that we achieved tonight before we got to the point where we had to recommit a number of votes. The real people who have had to endure our dancing around in terms of amendments and all of the debate that we have had have been the Aboriginal people. I believe that, in terms of the bill which will now go to the House of Representatives in which the government has achieved virtually most of its objectives, it is the Aboriginal people who are the losers.

The Democrats were certainly heartened to see Senator Harradine reject the unfair six-year sunset clause and also to vote on the very recent recommitted amendment of the Labor Party, because we believe that that is the best option in terms of the threshold test. I have to say that I think all of us were chastened today when we saw the indigenous people leave this parliament in tears. They were in tears because they knew that they were not going to get a fair and just outcome. They knew that, despite all of their efforts, the intransigence of the government would result in a bad outcome for Aboriginal people, and they were right. We know that they are in a state of deep grief tonight. They have been on my phone in tears, trying somehow or other at this late stage to get a better outcome. Our hearts are with them.

It makes the Democrats very sad that it had to come to this before we would pay attention to the fact that the people most affected are those who, in the end, were not only the original owners of this land but the nurturers and keepers also of a land to which we came very late. But they kept it for us and they would like to make a contribution to the future of Australia, a contribution which is unique and valuable and precious which they alone can make. If we continue to shut the door against that contribution, then we will never be the nation that I am sure we all want to be.

At the beginning of the debate, we said that we would keep faith with the High Court's decision on Wik. We accepted that the 1993 legislation had some problems and needed some fixing to make it more workable, less vulnerable to ambit claims and fairer all around. But we said that we would not support extinguishment of native title rights which may co-exist with pastoralist rights on leasehold land. We have maintained this position right up to this moment.

Throughout the process we have sought to represent the interests of the National Indigenous Working Group; a group established to negotiate their rights. But it takes at least two parties to negotiate and the government has not had a bar of it. I consider it a privilege to have been able to facilitate, to the extent that we are able, the indigenous position. It has for me been the most memorableâand in some ways sad in terms of outcomeâexperience of my parliamentary career.

On behalf of the NIWG, the Democrats co-sponsoredâwith Senator Margetts and the Greensâthe working group's position in total. We did it in December last year and we would not flinch from doing it again. So it is in accordance with the wishes of indigenous people and in accordance with our sense of fairness, justice and humanity that the Australian Democrats will oppose the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] , as indeed we did in 1997.

In doing so, we send a clear message to Prime Minister John Howard and his coalition government. The message is this: as the trustees of the integrity of this nation, you have failed to serve all of your people; as the custodians of reconciliation, you have abrogated your responsibilities; and as the leadership of this nation, you have failed in your office. Justice has not been done with this legislation. It does contain Tim Fischer's bucket loads of extinguishment, to which we should now read `bucket loads of dispossession'.

We approached this bill, as we did in 1997, with an aim to make good the government's legislation, but the government has not shared that goal. The government has not approached this debate in good faith, I believe. It is unfortunate that, in the government's quest for a double dissolution, it is comfortable in the use of indigenous people as an electoral football.

For me the most telling part of this debate was when I asked Senator Minchin what the cost was to indigenous people of cultural decimation, the stolen generations and, in deed, the cost of genocide. He did not have an answer. He has not been silent, however, on the alleged cost to industry of native title. That is the problem. Today indigenous people walked out of this parliament, their eyes filled with tears and their hearts heavy with sadness. I share their sadness and I am not ashamed to say that I shed a tear with them.

Out of this debate one thing has been certainâthat is, while the government have been successful in breaking the hearts of our indigenous brothers and sisters, they will never break their spirit. They are survivors in this land and long after we have gone their descendants will endure.

Politics has taken precedence over principle in this debate and that is sad. But ultimately the path to coexistence and reconciliation is on the ground with ordinary people working things out face to face. That process will continue, regardless of the laws made in this place and all the divisive rhetoric from the government. The Democrats will not be party to helping the government cynically manipulate this legislation for electoral purposes and that is why we reject the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] .

In closing I, too, thank all of the National Indigenous Working Group, but especially the person appointed to liaise with the Democrats, Aden Ridgeway, and all of the parliamentary staffâthe greatest bunch of civil servants I have ever come across. They are wonderful people. I also want to thank the team which worked closely with meâJonathan Tonge, John Davey, Susan Brown, Jim Downey and Vivienne Wynterâall of my colleagues who have stood with me in this debate and, of course, all Democrat staffers.

talk.start.para: âIt is probably appropriate in my third reading contribution that I read out the words of the statement made today by Gatjil Djerrkura and Geoff Clark from ATSIC on the process.

speech.para: In a press release dated today and headed `Political process fails indigenous people', they say:
The native title legislation before the Senate is unacceptable to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and should be voted down.
We agree the National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title has done its best to communicate its concerns to Parliamentarians but can do no more.

The legislative package is unfair, unjust and discriminatory. As such it is setting the foundations for long-term and bitter division in the Australian community. Given the course of the debate so far, any compromise reached in the Senate today is certain to fall far short of the expectations of indigenous Australians.

The government has been single-minded in its determination to reverse the success indigenous people have achieved in the highest court in the land. Even when succeeding with most of its legislation, the government has come back to continue the job of destroying the prospects for exercising our rights.
We face considerable extinguishment of our native title property rights in a way that goes far beyond the common law.
Miners have been rewarded because the states that ignored the federal law have been allowed to validate mining titles issued without regard for the Native Title Act.
Pastoralists have been rewarded with the potential for a wide range of diversification despite the terms of their leases. The implications of this go beyond the concerns of indigenous people.
Let there be no doubt that the legislation as it stands will serve neither the interests of future generations of indigenous Australians nor non-indigenous Australians.
It seems we can have no faith in the government to protect our existing rights but we will continue to resist this legislation by all the legal means possible.

It became quite clear during the course of the last few weeks, but especially today, that there could be nothing but a shameful outcome to this debate. There is the chance for the Senate to still do something for the indigenous people of Australia, and that is to vote in such a way as to indicate they have listened to the callâthe call made here by the National Indigenous Working Group and the call that I know many senators have heard from a wide variety of sources to vote down this bill.

People are watching not just to see the outcome of what the government will or will not do with its bill, and that is quite clear, they also want to see what the intentions are of any alternative government in relation to this bill. That is why I implore, urge, beg the ALP to do the right thing now and state by your vote what you would do when you are next in government. Voting for this bill continues the shame.

I want to express my personal thanks to Matthew Fagan for his tireless work, to Alan Carter for keeping things together, to Gary Coor for keeping us sane and providing legal advice, to the National Indigenous Working Group for their amazing work, to my colleague Senator Bob Brown, to Margaret and Ben and the rest of our staff, and to Rosemary Laing and the Senate clerks.

I would also like to give a special thanks to Senator John Woodley and John Davies of the Democrats for their working with us so helpfully and closely to get a result which we believed would be much, much closer to justice than has been achieved tonight. I thank all those people who, when the times were tough, managed to get through letters, phone calls and faxes of support. As I say, the only potential for not bringing total shame may be that the Senate provides the message to the government and the community that this bill is unacceptable.

talk.start.para: âI wish simply to commend this bill to the House of Representatives, to the Prime Minister, to the government and to the Australian people. I will be voting for the third reading. I believe that that is the responsible thing to do, because I have a firm view that this bill should become the law of the land in the spirit of recognition and reconciliation. It has provisions better than the bill that was presented to the Senate. It is a better bill for achieving a fair, decent, just and honourable outcome for all affected by the native title issue.

speech.para: This bill is based on certain fundamental principles. First, common law native title rights, as recognised by the historic Mabo decision, are preserved. They have not been further eroded, reduced or rendered valueless. I believe that that is the objective of all who have participated in the debate on this issue in this chamber: it may be their desire but, unfortunately, the acts do not meet with their desire. But the bill does not further erode, reduce or render valueless those native title rights. Second, there is a framework for government, corporations and individuals to take into consideration those native title rights and interests when their activities may seem to be affected or reduced by them. Third, there is a recognition that the system for the recognition and determination of native title rights and interests must be workable and fair to all involved. Fourth, recognised weaknesses and shortcomings in Australia's native title law are reduced or eliminated by this bill.

With this bill the Senate has, I believe, achieved such an outcome. There have been many individuals and sources who have contributed to this result. Of the government's 90 amendments, I have supported probably 90 to 95 per cent of them. Other successful amendments were proposed by other parties within this chamber and by me. There is, in this bill, I believe, a just balance for both indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. This bill preserves the common law native title rights of indigenous Australians and, unlike the unamended bill from the House of Representatives, does not seek to bring about extinguishment of those interests when such interests have not been extinguished at common law.

The bill preserves the right to negotiate for registered native title claimants and does not restrict or diminish the areas in which this important entitlement applies. It is one of the guarantees which this parliament has given to our indigenous people to preserve and enhance their common law native title rights and interests. The government's proposals, I suggest, would have seriously reduced those rights, with no compensating benefits to indigenous Australians. New procedures, including significant involvement of state based systems, for the determination of native title are features of this bill. These are new and relatively uncharted waters, and I would have thought that the response by the states would have been more encouraging than it was late this afternoon.

The rights of indigenous people and their native title interests are further protected by the new provisions in this bill on the relationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and the Native Title Act. Where any of the terms of the act or acts based upon such terms are ambiguous in their meaning and in their effect, such ambiguities are to be resolved consistent with the RDA. This is an important protection for indigenous interests.

A principal feature of this bill is the recast applications and registration procedure for native title claims. The bill introduces a claims procedure which should ensure that genuine native title claimants will have their claims registered. These claims will clearly set out the facts upon which the claimants rely for a community claim authorised by that community. The application to the land and other interests flows from their traditional laws and customs, observed by them as practicable. In this way, the claimants establish their descent and connection with the particular area where their forebears lived in 1788. The claims procedures have made provision for recognising the tragic history of families who have become part of the stolen generation or who, in respect of their traditional lands, were excluded by land-holdersâthe locked gates phenomenon. The claims process provides that the claimants will usually be certified by their regional or state representative body who is charged with the task of supporting claims on behalf of the true native title holders in a given area.

The draconian requirement that the claimants must establish to the satisfaction of the registrar all the native title rights and interests set out in their applications or suffer loss of their whole claim has been reversed. Claimants must now be registered in respect of all rights and interests for which they have facts and circumstances in support to the satisfaction of the registrar. This is the registration process for the right to negotiate and is built upon a new claims procedure through filing in the Federal Court for native title claims which might not meet the registration test or do not seek the right to negotiate. This is a revised system reflecting three years of experience and has a wide consensus of support among the stakeholders, state governments and indigenous communities. If the government accepts the bill in the House of Representatives, this system should now bring virtually to an end the troubled episode of paper claims, widespread overlapping claims and other anomalies which have caused anger and frustration among both indigenous and non-indigenous Australians.

With the new threshold test which applies to claims filed since 27 June 1996, there is now the real prospect of a new start and the emergence of fewer but better researched and better based claims by genuine descendants of indigenous peoples who occupied various areas of Australia in 1778. I believe there are few non-indigenous stakeholders who are not now prepared to deal with genuine claimants with proper evidence of connection, descent and observance of traditional laws. Native title may finally begin to find its real place and level amongst the existing entitlements and the future development of our indigenous peoples. It is not a panacea for all ills suffered by our indigenous peoples, of course. It is truly regrettable that unrealistic hopes have been built around common law native title.

The new threshold and registration test is very important in this legislationâeven the one that was adopted in the last hour. It may represent a unique opportunity for the parliament to re-establish a viable native title claims process. If we get the threshold test right, I believe the government, the state governments, pastoralists, miners and the indigenous communities will be the strongest supporters. There will be no satisfactory alternatives on the issues that I have mentioned if this bill does not become law. I seek leave to have the remainder of my speech incorporated into Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

To the major stakeholders other than the indigenous, I simply say this: Native Title claims will be more transparent, more detailed and better handled in contrast to previous experience. This system can work and should be made a focus of cooperation and involvement by both pastoralists and miners.

Finally, I say to the Government that in this Bill more than 80 per cent of its proposals have been adopted. It is a more balanced and just bill than the Government's initial proposal. The last three months have seen the Government extensively amend the Bill after wide consultation. These amendments have been adopted, overwhelmingly.

There is no justification for the Government not to sign this Bill or even to contemplate sending the country to an election. It would be both unwarranted and unconscionable. It would also be completely worthless as a solution in the near future of the outstanding issues.
I do not believe that even in a worst case situation of a double dissolution there will be any speedy resolution to validation or to the claims process or to the other weaknesses in this legislation.
Any election on this Bill would mean the Government allowed political ideology to triumph over the national good and national reconciliation. It is a fearful prospect.
Australians both indigenous and non-indigenous deserve better.

This Bill may not be perfect. Little that this Parliament does ever achieves that standard. But this Bill is better than the Government's Bill and represents a significant improvement on the existing Native Title legislation.

All Australians, indigenous and non-indigenous are significantly advantaged. These advantages should be grasped immediately. This Bill should be voted into law by the Government in the House of Representatives .

talk.start.para: âFirstly, let me put something to rest. The bill, as amended, does not deliver 90 per cent of what the government wanted. In fact, only two points of the 10-point plan remain substantially intact as a result of the Senate's deliberations. That is 80 per cent gone, not 80 per cent won. None of the four sticking pointsâthe RDA, right to negotiate, threshold test and sunset clauseâhave gone through. Only validation and water management survive intact. The rest have all been amended in opposition to the government, some more than others.

speech.para: We can go through them point by point. One, validation: we will give that a tick, that remains satisfactory. Two, confirmation of extinguishment: that is not delivered because of the introduction of the concept of revival of native title interest. Three, provision of government services: not delivered and the situation is potentially worse than it is at present. Four, primary production: that has not been fully delivered because of the restrictions on diversification and off-farm activities.

Statutory access has not been delivered in its original form. The right to negotiate has been confirmed on pastoral leases. The proposed alternative state provisions have been rejected. There is no exemption for infrastructure. Renewal exemptions are heavily qualified. We are now up to point seven, future commercial and government development. This has not been delivered specifically on towns and cities and government infrastructure. Water we can give a tick to. Out of the whole 10-point plan, that is the second and last tick to get through.

The management of claims has not been delivered with the recent change tonight to the higher threshold test. The sunset clause went down. On agreements, the government opposed several amendments put by the opposition. On top of that there is the eleventh point, the RDA, which goes to the overall workability of the Native Title Act and seriously undermines it. So let us have no more about how much of the government's legislation has gone through, because so much of it has not.

I would like to now address the issue of a double dissolution. Just a couple of days ago we had the Deputy Opposition Leader, the former foreign affairs minister, Gareth Evans, make an offensive and extraordinary remark. He accused the Prime Minister of never being so happy as when he is bashing black fellas. This is a former minister of the Crown of the Commonwealth parliament, a QC and a person who entertained ambitions of leading the United Nations. If such a person finds the normal cut and thrust of politics too much, how will candidates new to politics in the heat of an election debate, with native title the big issue, be able to keep from making unhelpful comments? It is tempting to think that all debate in the public arena will be conducted as if it were in this chamber tonight during the committee stage. That debate was mostly restrained, careful and backed up by professional advice on complex issues. But come an election, the committee of the Senate will not be in charge.

So far throughout this debate the Greens and the Democrats have dominated the floor. This has resulted in a very uneven and unbal anced debate. There are hundreds of thousands of Australians who have entirely different views. What we have heard over the past fortnight is generally the narrow left wing view that is shared by a minority of Australian people. Those are the hard political facts which were borne out recently by research into the opinions on native title around the country. If this were not true, then Senator Brown would be the Prime Minister and Senator Margetts would be the Treasurer. But for all their monopoly of the debate, they are way off the mark. The debate and a double dissolution will be out of their hands and run away to who knows where.

This has been a most frustrating debate for me and my constituentsâthe families of the bush, black and white, and the workers, black and white, who depend on our great rural and mining industries. Let there be no doubt that Labor has spearheaded the defeat of an acceptable regime for native title. Labor has given way to its left wing. The left wing has hijacked the debate. Labor has let down the blue-collar workers in their hundreds of thousands who work in agriculture and mining and whose families form the core of regional communities. Labor has put the ribbon wearers in front of the workers in mills, abattoirs, sugar mills, food processing factories and minesâthe support services and their employees.

Labor has forgotten the true believers. Labor has abandoned black and white in regional Australia. Labor has said to them, `We don't need you. We don't want your families to have a secure financial future and jobs for your kids. We would rather see the $30 billion go offshore instead of into mining ventures.' Labor is saying, `We would rather see delay after delay, court hearing after court hearing, than see families get a break.'

We have heard about the tears of Aboriginal people tonight, but I want to tell you that I have seen other tearsâtears of frustration in farming families trying to get their message across in this hostile environment here in Canberra. The debate in the Senate has been monopolised by the Greens. I believe that black and white families stand to gain more from a properly performing primary sector which recognises the common law right of native title while settling appropriate parameters on the statutory right to negotiate. I believe the $30 billion forgone this decade in mining projects is a tragic waste of potential for black and white families.

I believe the government's proposal is the way forward for all Australians. That is the inclusive way. A double dissolution is the divisive way and the only democratic option left if this bill is amended beyond the capacity of a duly elected government. I ask the Senate to reconsider its position.

talk.start.para: âI cannot support or commend this bill and certainly will not beâ

speech.para: Senator Boswell interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Can I have some order please, Senator Boswell.
âOrder! Senator Boswell! Can I have some order and silence. Senator Brown has the call.
âWe will not be voting for this bill.
âSurprise, surprise!

âThe interjections from those opposite indicate that they recognise what they expected. They got what they expected because there was such consistency in the stand that we took in this legislative debate. I want to, at the outset, thank Margaret Blakers and Ben Oquist on my staff and the staff of all of those in the Democrats and Greens corner of this chamber. I also want to thank my fellow Green member, Dee Margetts, who has been such a remarkably good advocate for returning fairness to this legislation, and Senator John Woodley, who has also brought a great deal of the honour to this debate that Senator Harradine spoke about.

speech.para: Why we will not be voting for this and why I suspect the Labor Party will not vote for it either is because, as Senator Bolkus has said, this amended bill gives the government 90 per cent of what it wants. Senator Harradine said it is 95 per cent of what it wants. Whichever way you look at it, that sums it up. That means the indigenous people get 10 per cent of what they want or five per cent of what they want. You can take it variously.

Let me quickly reiterate what is lost as far as they are concernedâthat is, their right to negotiate on the future of their lands and their lives in almost all respects into the future, the exception being mining, with some restrictions put on that. We recognise their claim after so long a period of suppression to their land but then deny them any say `in the future'. No wonder the National Indigenous Working Group, with tears, as has been commented on today, has finally turned their backs on this parliament, that they should have expected a better outcome from, and walked out today.

Let me repeat what they said. They described this bill, this Howard government 10-point plan, as an immoral and indecent proposal by the government which takes away fundamental rights of indigenous Australians. Whichever way you look at it, what we have ended up with in the Senate tonight is an immoral and indecent proposal by the government which takes away 90 per cent of the fundamental rights of indigenous Australians by the descriptions of others in this place. Moreover, the Indigenous Working Group says that this bill will be challenged every step of the way. They then made a call to the people of Australia to stand strong with them.
I want to quote the Prime Minister of this country when he delivered a personal apology to the indigenous people at the Aboriginal reconciliation convention in Melbourne in May this year. He said:

Personally, I feel deep sorrow for those of my fellow Australians who suffered injustices under the practices of past generations towards indigenous people. Equally, I am sorry for the hurt and trauma many people here today may continue to feel as a consequence of those practices.
Australians of this generation should not be required to accept guilt and blame for past actions and policies over which they had no control.
The problem is that there is grand theft of indigenous rights built into this legislation as amended, let alone the original proposition that came into this place. There is the theft of those rights.

The Prime Minister has to accept guilt and blame for not only that larceny of indigenous people's rights but also the consequences which this country as a whole will have to bear as a result of that theft as we go into the next century. The indigenous people cannot be expected to simply give, give and give, while their aspirations for the future are taken from them. The point has come where I expect you can hear the signs, in the anger of some of the submissions we have had put to us in the last two weeks, that there will be a rebellion against this continued threat.

I finish with this. There was the stealing of the lands and the horrible history that we all have to live with following 1770 and 1788. There has been the disaster of the stolen generation. Here tonight, the Senate and this parliament, whether you look at the amended bill or the original one that came in here, is being asked to give its approval to the stealing of rights from the indigenous people of this country. Is there anybody who is going to be party to that theft who is going to say, `And they should cop it'? Is there anybody who really says, `We cannot understand that the indigenous people should be not satisfied with this taking away of their rights and that there should be no reaction into the future and that reaction is not going to affect all Australians'? It is going to be to the detriment of all Australians, and I feel ashamed that we could not get a better outcome from the rows of thinking, representative Australians that we have in this place. I will feel more ashamed if it is just left to the Democrats and the Greens to be here to vote against this piece of legislation. One of the problems is that the indigenous people have essentially had to put up with the frustration of not being able to take part in this debate and have had to contend with trying to lobby as best they could, take second best and then take the consequences without having a real say.

Finally, the working group has called on supporters in their press release today to ensure the 10-point plan is thrown out and to work closely with indigenous Australians to achieve this. I endorse that call. We Greensâ and I am sure it is the same for the Democratsâwill be endorsing that call if we do get an election, and it appears obvious that that is what is going to happen as a result of this legislation. There will be a great challenge on every thinking Australian to search their heart as to whether they want to be part of the theft that is involved in this legislation too. This is a matter for changing votes. This is a matter for people reconciling themselves to history and making sure they do not compound it into the future. The challenge is to hear what the indigenous people are saying and to stand shoulder to shoulder with them, no matter how turbulent the coming months are, to ensure that they get a better deal in the coming century.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI conclude this third reading debate by saying that I personally am very disappointed by the outcome of now, I think, 87 hours of debate on this bill. The government has approached the period since December in good faith, has sought to consult, discuss and thrash around all the issues involved among the parties involved in this debate to see if there was any way in which we could resolve our differences and get a bill that was acceptable to the Senate within the framework of government policy. And in that vein we moved 99 government amendments to this bill in the course of this debate which were all in that spiritâdesigned to address concerns raised by the other parties in the original bill back in November-December. But, regrettably, another 100-odd anti-government non-government amendments to the bill have also been accepted by the Senate and we are not able to accept them.

speech.para: Our approach to this whole issue has been to try in a practical way to identify the real problems with the Native Title Act, to fix those problems after four years experience of that act and, most particularly, to incorporate the consequences of the Wik decision, which were manifest and quite significant, into the Native Title Act.

You have to keep remembering that the Native Title Act, for all the goodwill with which it was passed, is not working for the benefit of Aboriginal Australians. We still only have two determinations of native title after four and a bit years of operation of that act, one of which resulted in the extinguishment of that native title. The other one is the result of an agreement by, of all people, the Queensland government for the exercise of native title rights on DOGIT land in Queensland. So it is a very bad outcome for Aboriginal people from the operation of the Native Title Act, which manifestly does not work. We have tried to fix it. From my point of view, we have spent two years now developing a package of amendments to this bill, and I am particularly frustrated that we still have not yet seen any amendments to the act.

Tonight the Senate has finally passed amendments to the act which are unacceptable again in four out of four of the key areas. For a while, we had two out of four, but that was before lunch. After lunch we lost one of them, and after dinner we lost another one. So we are back down to zero out of four from our point of view. They really are fundamental. It is not fair or accurate to say that we got 90 per cent of it and we should take it. If you get the building built, but the lifts do not work, the building is no use to you. Frankly, we have got a building where the lifts and the lights do not work.

Apart from the four key areas, there are also a range of amendments in other areas that we have not identified publicly but which cause significant concern and hardship to rural and regional Australia. Indeed, it would appear that the bill is actually worse than it was last December.

I would reiterate that, from our point of view, this bill always was a compromise. We had a lot of differences in our own ranks. We worked them through. We came up with a bill which everyone in the coalition could live with. It did not give any particular interest group in the community all that it demanded of usânot the Indigenous Working Group, not the mining industry, not the farming industry. We approached this from the point of view of our national responsibilities to produce legislation in the national interest which did not give any interest group what it sought from us.

But the bill does fundamentally accept the Mabo and Wik decisions. It does seek in a fair and practical way to build those decisions into Australia's land management system. This is a difficult concept for all Australiansâa common law, inalienable property right only available to people of a particular race. That is not an easy thing to build into 200 years of settled statutory law. We have tried hard, and we think that what we produced is fair and equitable. All the way through we have had as our criteria fairness, equity, practicality and certainty. We wanted a workable outcome. We have not got it. The Senate has passed amendments that do make the bill, in our view, unworkable.

I simply finish by thanking all those senators who have spent some 87 hours in here together debating this bill. I think it was debated in general terms in a spirit of goodwill and generosity, apart from a few differences that seemed to occur from time to time on that side of the chamber, which we watched with amusement. But I do think we have, as senators, established once again that the Senate is a chamber in which these very serious national issues can be debated fairly and sensibly, and without the rancour which often distracts those in the other chamber.

I particularly thank the Wik task force on my left who have worked long and hard to try to produce a sensible outcome. I think everybody on both sides respect their work. I want to thank my own personal staff, particularly Senate officials, for what they have done. I conclude by wishing everybody a very happy Easter.
Question put:
That the bill be now read a third time.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
