talk.start.para: âI will be brief in my comments this evening. Despite the late hour, I felt the significance of recent journalistic events must be placed on the public record. Distortion and manipulation of the truth by members of the Fourth Estate has been revealed to me this evening. The manipulation follows a curious path following an apparently misleading article entitled `Catholic warning to Libs on race poll' which appeared on page 2 of the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday, 3 April.

speech.para: The reporter suggested that Catholic priests will urge an anti-coalition vote on Wik. These comments are attributed to Bishop Chris Saunders. Bishop Saunders came to me last Friday, distressed by the article's untruths. To correct the public record, Bishop Saunders wrote to the editor of the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 April. He sought to disassociate himself from the headline and from some of the remarks attributed to him in the article, stating clearly that he did not say that Catholic priests would tell people to vote against the government.

It is obvious from his letter that the journalist deliberately attempted to position the Catholic church in a party political manner to incite the racial debate in line with comments by Gareth Evans reported in the same article. The Sydney Morning Herald contacted Bishop Saunders and told him they would not print the letter unless it was revised. Bishop Saunders sent a revised letter dated 7 April 1998. On 7 April, Antony Lawes of the Sydney Morning Herald provided a letter to Bishop Saunders dated 5 April which he said the paper would be happy to publish. It was another blatant attempt by the paper to protect their own and position the Catholic church for the pending campaign. Bishop Saunders responded to Mr Lawes in a fax dated 7 April. He wrote:

I am in receipt of your proposed revision of my letter to the Editor. I am not satisfied that your proposed revision adequately communicates my dissatisfaction with the headline `Priests attack Libs in Race Poll' and some aspects of the article which followed.

In good faith I have already revised the letter once so as to emphasise the headline and not the report. However, the opening remarks attributed to me in the article are also of some concern for me as they are misleading, especially when placed in the context of the above headline.

I was at pains in my interview to be non-party political and I am much concerned that extremism and moral misconduct, during a race poll, is a distinctly dangerous possibility at the hands of any politician of any political persuasion. The point isâI never once inferred or stated that `Catholic priests would urge an anti-coalition vote at a Wik election'.
Bishop Saunders asked Lawes to publish his letter of 7 April unedited. He wrote:
If you will not do so I would like you to inform me as to the reason.
The editor has not done so as Bishop Saunders wished.

In today's edition of the Sydney Morning Herald âthat is, Thursday, 9 April 1998âthe editor sunk to new depths in journalism and published his own letter in the name of Bishop Saunders. We often hear from journalists the cry of freedom of speech. The Sydney Morning Herald has denied Bishop Saunders the opportunity to correct the misrepresentation made against him and denied him his freedom of speech. I seek leave to incorporate the letters in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The letters read as followsâ
The Editor
Letter to the Editor
Sydney Morning Herald
Sydney N.S.W.
Dear Sir,

a misleading headline led an article in the SMH (2 April 1998) based on an interview with me. The Headline suggested that Catholic Priests will be telling people from the pulpit not to support the Government in a forthcoming election. This preposterous idea, according to the article, came from me. I wish to disassociate myself from the headline and from some remarks attributed to me in the article.
I did not say that Catholic priests will tell people to vote against the government.

What I did say was that if the forthcoming election devolves into a race poll and racist remarks are uttered about Aboriginal people and that the campaign is conducted in an immoral manner, by any candidate, then I would hope that priests would denounce such tactics and behaviour from the pulpit. I did not have in mind any particular candidates of any one party and I was not excluding the possibility that my remarks might well be applicable to circumstances surrounding any candidate of independent status.

The prospect of a Race Poll continues to worry me. Such worries are justified in the face of the invective witnessed last week in Parliament in the course of the debate between the Prime Minister and the Deputy leader of the Opposition.
I hope that Catholic people, ordained and non-ordained, will condemn any actions and words used by candidates to inflame race relations and slur the innocent.
I appreciate this opportunity to set the record straight and to correct the injustice of inaccurate reporting and a misleading headline. I await your apology.
Yours faithfully,
+Christopher Saunders
Bishop of Broome

I did not have in mind candidates of any one party, and I was not excluding the possibility that my remarks might well be applicable to a candidate of independent status.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening once again on the issue of this government's management of the IT outsourcing program. Over the last two years I have had the opportunity to track this program and explore the role of OGIT and the Department of Finance and Administration in the process. As a result, there are a number of issues that are of great concern, largely going to issues of probity and the degree of public accountability attributed to some decisions regarding contracts let as part of or associated with the IT outsourcing program.

speech.para: There are several areas of concern. The first relates to how this government managed to completely compromise a model of selective sourcing that utilised the in-house strengths and still capitalised on the innovation our private sector has to offer. They have departed from the principles of competitive tendering and contracting out established by the Industry Commission report by excluding the opportunity for existing in-house services to benchmark their costs and subsequently compete for the work. The whole approach won the support of only the Department of Finance and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in the original cabinet submission upon which the government justified the decision to outsource in this way. All other agencies voiced a plethora of concerns.

The second area of concern was the appalling disregard for the established competitive tendering process witnessed with the piggybacking of the Department of Finance contract on a pre-existing contract between IBM and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. There is no paper trail with the negotiations surrounding this deal. It was done over the phoneâa practice that has since become established in the Department of Finance.

It is an interesting point that the agency heads involved in this deal were not prepared to sign off on it, although technically they could under the procurement guidelinesâalbeit they did, in my view, breach those procurement guidelines by bypassing the competitive tendering process. Ultimately, it was referred to the minister for signature. This contractual windfall for IBM was further expanded without competitive tendering processes being adhered to when DAS was abolished and the remaining sections integrated into the Department of Finance, subsequently called the Department of Finance and Administration.

An interesting point is that during this process issues of probity were raised consistently given that IBM indeed had a contract with the Department of Finance at the time relating to the outsourcing work that was being done by that department. The probity auditor subsequently appointed by the department to address concerns, Mr Stephen Marks, was appointed following a direct solicitation by Gillian Marks via a phone call after competitive tenders for this contract had all been rejected.

Another area of grave concern was the negative impact on Australian businesses. The government, in their laziness, opted for huge multi-agency outsourcing contracts that are only accessible by the big six IT corporations, permanently relegating Australian IT firms to subcontract status. This lazy policy has angered our innovative Australian IT sector. Sadly, we have already experienced the downside of this model with Select, a local IT company, coming out worse off in a tussle with EDS. EDS recently won the Customs IT outsourcing contract, and Select, although they successfully positioned themselves early in what was proclaimed by Minister Fahey to be the shining example of a successful partnership between local and multinational, as I said, came off worse.

Minister Fahey went on to make hay with his industry development clause in the cluster 3 contract which, interestingly, attracted criticism from both the small and large players at the time. Again, this was lazy policy, but I will return to that industry development clause shortly.

Upon the awarding of the first contract under the program nine months after schedule, again the minister spoke patronisingly of a role eked out for local companies, and he revelled in the scope of industry development requirements that he claimed would be enforced under the terms of the contract. However, there is no scope to scrutinise the adherence to the industry development obligations provided for in this contract. The industry is forced to rely on the minister's word for it, and credibility is something that Minister Fahey does not have. Unless this information is available to be scrutinised publicly, it remains a farce, and all that puff and bluster about penalties means nothing when it comes from Minister Fahey.

The whole industry knows how obtuse he is. The whole industry knows that a minister who forces a formal, legally enforceable gag upon any interested party, including their spouses, has something to hide. Indeed, this is precisely what happened with respect to this government's IT outsourcing contracts. No-one is allowed to participate or to involve themselves either from a department point of view, as employees of the Public Service, or indeed as private sector parties expressing an interest, unless they sign this confidentiality deed.

I would now like to turn to what Minister Fahey, his office, and formerly OGIT, now the Office of Asset Sales and IT Outsourcing, I believe have to hide. There has been a series of contracts entered into by the Department of Finance and Administration that raise serious questions of probity. The pre-existing relationships of the beneficiaries of these contracts are also of great interest.

Shaw Pittman Potts and Trowbridge, a US based legal firm, were engaged by OGIT on the instruction of Greg Barns, an adviser in Minister Fahey's office. Yasmin King, operating under the company name of Flexible Resources, was also engaged by OGIT in the same way. Both Shaw Pittman and Yasmin King provided advice to the former Premier of South Australia, Dean Brown, with respect to the South Australian whole of government IT outsourcing contract with EDS.

Although it was the former chief of OGIT, Andy McDonald, who entered into these contracts, it was apparently done with the explicit intervention of John Fahey's office. Dr McDonald's subsequent resignation has been shamelessly used by departmental officialsâpresumably at the behest of the minister's officeâto deflect responsibility for these decisions, as was witnessed in the most recent round of Senate estimates.

I have previously reflected harshly upon the motivation of Dr McDonald's sudden resignation, but these issues cause me to reflect now upon his position as agency chief, having to acquiesce to the demands of the minister. I guess it is not so surprising that he pulled the pin.

With respect to Ms King's contract, worth $320,000, she was required to advise on industry development guidelines. She is quoted in the Adelaide Advertiser as saying, `I have a unique set of experiences and they saw some benefit in using them.' Shaw Pittman Potts and Trowbridge were also contracted to advise on industry development. Their contract is worth around $5 million but, as yet, remains ambiguous because it is set in US dollars and the final amount will relate to the exchange rate. A quite extraordinary fact relating to the Shaw Pittman contract is that estimates evidence shows that this multimillion dollar contract is only for three people over a period of 12 months in that particular office.

Cutler and Co. was contracted to provide advice on industry development to the value of $70,000 and Gillian Marks has responsibility for industry development. There is another interesting link with Gillian Marks, which was also apparently involved in the provision of advice to the former Premier of South Australia, Dean Brown, on both the Adelaide Water and the EDS contracts. At the same time as all this advice was flowing to the government on industry development requirements, it is apparent that the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism drafted the industry development clause that ended up in the cluster 3 contract.

What is the net result of this? We have over $5 million being spent or allocated by the Office of Government and Information Technology, now the Office of Asset Sales and Information Technology Outsourcing, for the explicit purpose of industry development. None of these contracts was subject to competitive tender. The question has to be asked: who are these people working for? It is quite clear that the outcomes of the industry development clause that ended up in cluster 3 do not serve the interests of Australian industry. We heard evidence before the Senate inquiry into IT outsourcing, which has already reported to this place, that there is a great deal of dissatisfaction, frustration and anger amongst Australian IT companies. What next for Minister Fahey? What is the next step for the government's IT outsourcing program? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 9 March 1998:

question.para: Given that there are approximately 1300 East Timorese in Australia seeking to escape persecution under the Indonesian occupation of East Timor by seeking asylum under the Domestic Protection Visa category (866); given that the Government is threatening to deport these refugees on the grounds that they have a `right to live in a safe third country', namely Portugal; and given that on 21 February 1996 the then Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) stated categorically to members of the friends of East Timor (WA) at the campaign office of Dee Kelly, Liberal candidate for Perth, that: `under a Coalition Government, Australian authorities, in assessing the claims of East Timorese for refugee status, would consider these claims solely against Indonesia, without reference to the dubious issue of Portuguese citizenship', reaffirming his statement in the Australian newspaper on 12 October 1995 that, `the fact is Australia has never considered the people of East Timor as anything but Indonesian since 1979, the latest claim by Mr Keating that they are Portuguese is simply absurd and hypocritical':
(1) (a) Is the Minister aware of the comments made by Mr Downer; and (b) why has the Coalition's policy on this issue apparently changed.

(2) Does the Australian Government regard Indonesia as having sovereignty over the land, the people and the natural resources of East Timor; if so, why does the Australian Government believe that Portugal should take responsibility for East Timorese refugees seeking asylum in Australia.

(3) Has Australia, rightly, accepted refugees of the Jewish faith from the former Soviet Union and other places in recent times, despite the fact that Israel offers a `right of return' policy for anyone of the Jewish faith to take up residency in Israel; if so, why has the Australian Government refused to allow East Timorese refugees asylum in Australia when they are offered far less certain citizenship rights in Portugal.

(4) Is the Minister aware of the nationwide Christian Sanctuary Network which intends to harbour East Timorese threatened with deportation; if so, how does the Government expect to proceed against nuns, priests, war veterans and other notable citizens when they undertake the civil disobedience which they have solemnly pledged to carry out on this issue.

(5) (a) How is it intended to remedy the current discriminatory practice with regard to visitor visas, in which East Timorese are effectively being banned from being granted visas in cases where other, non-East Timorese, Indonesians would have little trouble entering Australia; and (b) is the Minister aware of the great distress being caused amongst East Timorese families who are being denied access to their relatives in genuine cases of intended short-term visits, for example for weddings and births.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the follwing answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) This Government's policy towards applicants for refugee status in Australia has not changed.

The Government's position is that each application for refugee status is decided on its individual merits and on a case by case basis with reference to the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees ("the Refugees Convention"), as amended by the 1967 Protocol Relating to the Status of Refugees. The Refugees Convention is given legislative force in Australian law through the provisions of the 1958 Migration Act.

Under the Refugees Convention, a person should not be afforded international protection if they have effective protection from a country of their nationality (that is, a country other than that from which they fear persecution). You would be aware that in its decision on 2 May 1997, the Full Bench of the Federal Court decided on the nationality of East Timorese asylum seekers (the Jong case). The court found no legal error was made by the RRT in the determination that certain East Timorese people (including Mr Jong, the applicant in the matter) are Portuguese nationals. The question in that case, however, related to the effectiveness of Portuguese protection. This is an issue that was sent back to the RRT for consideration.

(2) The issue of Australia's de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor is totally separate from and irrelevant to the issue of the determination of applications for refugee status under the Refugees Convention.

The issue of whether an applicant for refugee status from East Timor is a national of Portugal or has access to Portuguese nationality, and therefore may fall within the provisions of Article 1A(2) of the Refugees Convention is solely a legal question which has been determined by the Full Bench of the Federal Court with regard to the existing Portuguese nationality laws.
(3) Australia has not recently resettled people of the Jewish faith from the former Soviet Union as refugees.

Our humanitarian resettlement program has, however included a Special Assistance Category (SAC) for Minorities of the Former USSR. This SAC has helped individuals usually resident in the former USSR who may not have met the definition of a `refugee' under the UN Refugees Convention, but who have nevertheless suffered substantial discrimination or severe distress because of their ancestry or religious affiliation. Such individuals had to have had close family links to Australia. This SAC is being closed because of changed circumstances in the USSR.

If a person of the Jewish faith living outside Israel makes an application for a protection visa, and it appears that this asylum seeker has effective Israeli nationality according to Israeli nationality laws, then that fact would be investigated and that person may not engage Australia's protection obligations.

With regard to the Portuguese citizenship rights of certain East Timorese, the Portuguese Government has made it clear that Portuguese nationals of East Timorese ethnicity have all the consequent rights and obligations of any other Portuguese citizen.
(4) I am aware of the nationwide Christian Sanctuary Network and its intention to harbour East Timorese threatened with removal.
Well meaning people are being encouraged to break the law by offering sanctuary to persons who may not have a right to remain in Australia. The Government urges those involved to obey the law.

(5) Each visa application is assessed by a delegated decision-maker against the provisions of the Migration Act and Regulations, and is considered on its individual merits. There are no blanket decisions applied to individual applicants because of their nationality, ethnicity or citizenship.

Australia's visitor program aims to facilitate the entry of overseas visitors. While every effort is made to keep formalities to a minimum, there are certain legal requirements that must be met by all applicants for a visitor visa to avoid abuses of the visitor program. Particular abuses, which have been of concern to successive Governments for the past 20 years, are visitors working unlawfully or overstaying their authorised period of stay. The legal criteria for the grant of a visitor visa require, amongst other things, that the applicant has adequate funds for their support for the period of the visit and that they intend a genuine visit to Australia. These criteria are the same regardless of the nationality of the applicant, or the part of the world where the application is lodged.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 12 March 1997:

question.para: With reference to a grant under the National Landcare Program in the name of the Boorowa Community Landcare Group for a demonstration site on the property of Mr David Marsh:

(2) Was funding for the provision of fencing included in the grant for the project; if so, what was the level of funding provided for that purpose.

(3) Did the planned erection of the fencing not proceed because it was considered to be not economically viable; if so; was the funding provided for that purpose returned to the Department; if not, why not.
(4) (a) What action did the department take to recover the funds; and (b) from whom.

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator Parer
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) The Boorowa Community Landcare Group (BCLG) applied for and received a National Landcare Program (NLP) grant of $19,780 in 1992-93. The grant application stated that the BCLG would use electric fencing around tree lots for grazing management until trees are above stock damage level.
